description: My new favorite Italian restaurant! If they can put more tomato sauces in the Cappellini Pomodoro, I would be loving it more!!
author: Jiahua S.

description: Love n firewood but only one thing please don't bring out my salad with my meal..food is always hottt and good especially the rock shrimp tortellini and always the rotisserie chicken. As you can see I went back again today... there is the most wonderful cashier Martha she always greet you with a smile .  Just as a side not I found out today if you want the salad  to share remember to tell them to make it an appetizer.  So that it won't come out with your meal.
author: RICHARD J.

description: I've been coming here for several years and the servers are consistently welcoming and helpful. The food is overpriced and mediocre but the restaurants as a homey feel and it's a great place to have a long conversation with friends.
author: SF R.

description: Firewood is a neighborhood staple. You don't go here for an incredible dining experience; you go to spend time with friends. It's almost always very easy to sit with a large group. Everyone lines up at the counter to order, then the meals are prepared quickly and typically arrive at the table in order. The staff is very nice and accommodating to substitutions. I've been coming here for years, and while there are occasional hiccups with orders, most of my experiences have been pleasant. The tortellini with firewood sauce is good, I also like the baked ziti. The pizzas are enjoyable, and salads are large and can come with a wide variety of toppings.
author: Russ S.

description: This was a solid dinner choice. I ordered the chicken parmigiana, very good portion and price. I gave 4/5 stars only because of the limited menu options. Enjoy!
author: Cris A.

description: Great value. The food is fresh and consistent. The staff is friendly, and have been there for many, many years. It's "fast-casual" but can also pass as a proper restaurant, although I probably wouldn't take a date here. I used to go more frequently for lunch, but they've changed their hours and only do lunch on weekends.
author: Eddie C.

description:
Great for when you want a sit down meal with a real plate and silverware experience, but under the efficient fast casual model where all ordering is done at the counter.  The food is comparable to other fast casual joints like The Grove, but obviously can't compare to a fancy Michelin 1-star restaurant.  It's solid eating at a reasonable price.

Chicken Parmigiana: The chicken portion was decent.  Generally nice and crispy (though a few sections were overcooked).  Came with the right ratio of sauce and cheese on top of the chicken.  The capellini was a bit disappointing though.  Would have preferred it to be more al dente.  Also, they seemed a bit stingy with the sauce; the pasta only got a few drippings from red sauce falling off the chicken.

Sauteed Swiss Chard, White Beans and Pancetta: I'm not a  big vegetable side guy, but loved this.  Probably because there were ample cubes of crispy pancetta.  But also because the white beans made it feel hearty.  Way more exciting than just wilted greens.

Honey-Dijon Chicken: Definitely ups the rotisserie chicken game by being drenched in a sticky and sweet honey-dijon glaze.  It's not quite Roli Roti good, but it sure beats Safeway.  The potatoes were decent, but paled in comparison the chicken.  The bread tasted stale and was generally uninteresting.
author: Adam B.

description: The food and fast casual service are reasons why they've lasted so long. Had a half roasted chicken which was delicious! The skin is still nice and crisp and the meat was moist. Served with a side of roasted potatoes. Ordered takeout and food was done within 8 minutes. Fast and delicious!
author: Thomas L.

description: Consist food, TONS of seating, wifi...I really like firewood. The staff are also super nice. My only -1 star is that it's quite pricy.
author: Colin D.

description: Firewood is a solid place to grab a decent meal that won't break your wallet. We tend to opt for a salad, which will easily feed two, and a pizza, which we also will split. You order your meal at the counter, grab a table and they will bring it to you. The place has always been clean, and the service very friendly.
author: Greg S.

description: Food was great and service was excellent. I had the chicken parm last time and they aren't skimpy with the chicken at all. I'll definitely be back.
author: Bob J.

description: I got the Margherita pizza, which comes straight out of a firewood oven. You order up front then there is plenty of seating. We went around 6 pm and it wasn't crowded. Nice for conversation and delicious food.
author: Ashley P.

description: I work nearby & had the pleasure of having lunch at the Firewood Cafe during my first week of employment. Since then, I have eaten there many times. I tried the penne with sausage & peppers and it was good. Bread and butter come with the entree and it is so delicious! The subsequent visits I ordered the Caesar salads. I'm like that, keeping it simple. The salads are not simple tho. You pick a protein if you like: chicken, shrimp, or salmon. Then choose three fixings: I like beets, feta cheese, roasted corn. I get the dressing on the side because the salads are huge, I have leftovers.
author: Rene C.

description:
Great food. I have dined in and gotten takeout. The salads and pizzas taste fresh and delicious. There can be a line out the door if you go at a very busy time. 
It would be a great place for an event.
author: Chris S.

description: Been coming here for years! I always get the shrimp tortellini in white wine cream sauce and the Caesar salad with mushrooms, blue cheese and corn. They're both the best and so satisfying! It's literally to die for!
author: Milan A.

description:
DO NOT COME HERE IF YOU ARE FROM OUT OF TOWN AND HAVE CHILDREN WITH YOU.  The Castro is the most OUT section of San Francisco, and on your way there you too may see a group of men wearing nothing but flip flops and strategically-wrapped aluminum foil, walking down the street looking like they just swallowed a bottle of Viagra and are 15 minutes from the recommended "call your doctor" time frame expiring.  How this is legal I don't know, but it was far from out of place among the assorted other men, wearing the likes of studded leather vests or short shorts, as if a Village People convention was in town (which... I mean... maybe it was.  Maybe it is every day.  I don't know.).

That said, I went to the Firewood Cafe with a group of four.  We didn't have trouble finding a place to park on the street, and the restaurant wasn't overcrowded (though it was pretty full by the time we left).  I got the jambalaya special, and the other orders from my group included pork loin, sausage pizza, and grilled shrimp.  The food was good.  Absolutely no complaints about my jambalaya, or the bites I had of pizza and pork.  The vegetable sides were flat-out excellent.  

I was confused as to whether this is a lunch counter-type of restaurant or a sit-and-wait type of restaurant, as you have to line up at the register to order, but then your food is brought out and staff are busily bussing tables and refilling drinks.  I rather wish it was one or the other.  My understanding is that they also do take-out, and I suppose if I had done that, then my confusion about the service model and my aversion to bringing my kids here would be set aside in favor of just enjoying the food.
author: Jeff T.

description:
I have come here twice on my visits to San Francisco. It is a great place located in the Castro District. The staff is very friendly and it's a casual spot. I have had their Kale salad and added Salmon and I have had their wood oven Salmon. Both are very good. 
There are only 3 salad options (Ceasar, Kale and Garden,  I believe is the 3rd choice) and they come with 3 toppings for a base price. Then you can add on a meat and more toppings for add'l price.  So by time I finished with my salad order my price went from $10.95 to about & 17.95.  I added the salmon which about $6-7 more I believe. And an extra side. So by time tax, tag and title was added it was almost $20 salad.. But it was so worth it.. The portion is very generous and it was down right delish! So that was my first time there.  
My second time there (this past time when I checked in) I got the wood oven Salmon dish with Swiss chard and roasted potatoes.. All I can say is mmm mmm good! The Swiss chard is sautéed and has white beans and onions and big bacon bits, which I didn't realize cause I don't really eat pork, (except bacon sometimes.. Lol) so ate a few and moved most of them to the side. And the potatoes are seasoned to perfection.. 
I came with 2 friends,  one that introduced me to the place and a coworker. One friend had a Kale salad with salmon and my other friend had a type of jambalaya dish, and each enjoyed their meal tremendously. This will definitely be a spot I will continue to come to when I am in San Fran.
author: Keja J.

description: Never disappointed after eating here! My choice is the Salmon or Caesar Salad w/grilled chicken. Both are always perfect. Wait time is very minimal and the wait staff are so attentive.
author: Lawrence D.

description:
It is always confusing to order here. With entrees I am always asked if I want "swiss chard" or the "vegetable". As swiss chard is a vegetable they should ask if I want swiss chard or the mixed/melody of vegetables as those are the two options. 
.
They used to give a complementary side of mixed olives. No more, I must ask for them specifically. If they want to avoid waste and be kinder, they could just offer them. Flatware is no longer available at the self-service station either so when I order coffee I cant mix my cream or sugar until I am eventually brought a spoon. And finally the employees throw dishes around so loudly Im on edge expecting to hear a breaking crash at any moment. 
.
On the positive side, I have not had a dish that I didnt like. And, they make the only thin crust pizza that I find so difficult to get in this neighborhood and I think it is GREAT.
author: Caesar A.

description: Great place to go with a group of friends. Wonderful Italian food. Consistent quality. Great service. Nice open atmosphere. Relaxed.
author: JD M.

description:
Firewood Cafe offers healthy eats.  I was told its the destination for the workout gurus because they serve free range organic chicken, and home grown veggies bought from local farmers.  They get busy and the line can stretch out the door, but they are quick to take your order.  

Make sure you order first, then take your seats.  They will bring your food to your table.  I do recommend their prosciutto pizza.  It is delicious.  Their herb chicken could use more seasoning, but the skin wasn't too bad. They give you huge portion and for about $12, you can have a good meal. 

Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description:
If you are looking to eat some staple Italian food, especially in a large group, this is a good go-to. Conveniently located near clubs and bars in the Castro District, even the cashier told me it's his favorite after party eatery. 

The food itself is nothing special but comes in a decently large portion for its price, so... awesome! I ordered the Penne ($12.25) which is tossed in a white wine cream sauce with prosciutto, shiitake mushrooms, and sweet peas. I sampled a few other dishes from my friends, including the House Tortellini ($12.50) which is stuffed with roasted chicken and cheese. Neither blew me away, but I would still come back here again. 

The line to order takes awhile for some reason, but the chefs put out all the food on a nearby counter that will entice you until you reach the register. The best part about Firewood is that they have an area with cups of prepoured iced water with lemon, as well as bowls of assorted olives. It's the little things that make Firewood worth returning to.
author: Stefanie C.

description: After my very last visit I must accept that I have mixed feelings about this restaurant. First thing to say, I love the complimentary marinated olives. This is a big plus because most of restaurants do not have anything complimentary aside bread or chips and they can't be compared to olives. I always wanted something different. The food at Firewood is good too. I have tried the roasted chicken, chicken parmagiana (this is great), salads (cesar is ok, just standard cesar salad) and pizzas (prosciutto and pesto are my favorite ones) and the quality is about similar to other restaurants that are overpriced. One thing to point though is that I that there is no service, I think it would be better if there were waiters to refill my soda, check back or offer desserts when I am about to finish my meal.
author: Melody C.

description: Enjoyed awesome food, quick service, and wonderful atmosphere in The Castro!  Great pizzas!  We had a group of 19 and the staff was remarkable & took us all in comfortably.  No stress at all!
author: Brent T.

description:
Note to management: Staff need more training!
Normally pretty good, however, on our last visit one of us asked for shrimp tortellini and was given chicken and bacon/ham instead. Mistakes happen, and the staff were apologetic, but they need to be more understanding and considerate toward diners' dietary preferences and restrictions in regards to kosher, halal and other personal, religious or cultural beliefs.
author: Foofa B.

description: Great!! You have to try the fettuccine!! Firewood cafe is my husband favorite place., we love it.
author: Maritza P.

description: This place was ok, but nothing special. My husband and I stumbled upon Firewood when we were looking for something to eat after the Giants game because we were on Muni, and just decided to get off on Castro. We got the angel hair pasta with marinara sauce, and it was ok. We also got two pizzas, one margarita and one pepperoni. I would say the margarita was the better of the two, but neither were anything to write home about. They were thin crust and the ingredients seemed fresh, but something was missing. Maybe the flavor of the crust, or maybe there could have been more cheese. I don't know. The service was fine and the actual restaurant was spacious and updated, but I think there are better options in Castro.
author: Steph L.

description: Chicken pesto pizza and shrimp salad..I'm gf ill take this stomach ache..food was amazing ..ordered the pesto chicken pizza with no peppers and onions..
author: Elisha S.

description:
Less than satisfying and not cheap. 

Pasta was overcooked, and the pizza really salty with a 'wood-fired' crust. Ok, maybe it was wood-fired, but some wood-firing's not gonna fix what tasted like a frozen pizza crust. 

What was good? Well the half roasted chicken. That was actually really good.

Bill without tip was about $50. And the food came out seriously staggered...like 20 minutes apart for each thing.

It was surprisingly busy for such a mediocre place. I must be missing something.
author: El B.

description: This place has consistently gone down hill for years. At 2pm nothing is fresh . The chicken was clearly cooked last night and reheated to death today. Not even edible. I will have to say in all fairness the staff is always very pleasant here.
author: John R.

description:
Simply gourmet 5 star menu with ingredients being as fresh as fresh gets. Sweet white corn freshly cut off of the cob. 

The atmosphere: a large modern, clean, positive-spirited, and calming. 

The staff: I was particularly happy with someone named Paoi, a happy, kind, and "at your service" type of person and very on point. Always smiling.

The salmon: so fresh, so juicy, so perfect, and I can be picky with fish. THIS was TASTy!


I would absolutely come here again. It seems like a place that would suit any occasion and any time of the day or evening would be a good time to come here.

Can't wait to try other dishes from here! Props to the chef.
author: Karina G.

description: Perhaps the best fresh food in the entire Castro neighborhood. Lots to choose from from the pizza to pastas lots of veggie sides and roasted mains all benefiting from the woodfired grill. Add a really nice staff in the open kitchen and the main floor this my choice as best of the Castro. The only question is "Why hasn't this been franchised throughout the country?"
author: Ken B.

description: I need to go here more often because I like the food - specifically the house tortellini with marinara sauce.  The restaurant is cafe style where you order the food at the counter and they bring it out to you.  The staff is nice and the place is clean.  I recommend!
author: Shaun W.

description:
Just had a dinner meeting here with eight friends. The cafe served two different kinds of chicken, roasted potatoes, Caesar salad, olives and three kinds of thin-crust pizza - pepperoni, mushroom and marguerita.
Everything was delicious. I particularly liked the Caesar salad and the mushroom pizza. So much food was served that everyone took home a box of leftovers.
Thanks to Firewood and its staff for a great meal.
author: Philip C.

description:
I should have came here first for dinner but went across the street for sushi instead. That was a BIG mistake. My fiancé and I finished up with our dinner at Takara Sushi and walked straight in here after we saw the number of people eating and looking like they enjoyed their meal. We were miserable and felt like we need something more satisfying. So we added more quarters to our meter and walked right in. 

Immediately, the staff greeted us and told us about their Specials. Their menu board is big and extensive from pizzas, pastas, to sides, and kid's menu. I almost got lost reading every word on that board and to find out they have a Specials menu almost made me faint. It took my fiancé a few minutes of calling my name before I was brought back to reality. I ended up ordering a Margherita pizza and a Chicken Fettuccine Alfredo. I know, it is so generic but my stomach was not up to eating anything complicated or gourmet for that matter. We wanted simple comfort food we can cry into after our disappointing sushi dinner. 

So once we got our food we started to dig in and I cannot believe how good the pizza was. Thin crust and baked perfectly. The Alfredo sauce was creamy and had broccoli and zucchini in it. The pasta was cooked perfectly as well. I almost choked on my tears while I ate my pasta. It was that good. The wait staff was wonderful. She came by and checked on us and refilled our drinks. It was like the dinner we should have had in the first place. We finally ended the night on a good note and after our simple Italian dinner we boxed our leftovers and went home. We were finally satisfied. 

I recommend this place if you find yourself in the neighborhood. It is a bit out of the way for me but I won't be surprised if I end up here with a group of my girlfriends on one of our gatherings. It is a very spacious restaurant that can accommodate large groups. If your group arrives early enough you can dominate the back room which can easily seat 10- 15 people. It is all open seating, so first come first served. High ceilings. Laid back atmosphere where you can easily fit in with your jeans or yoga pants. If you do dress up, like how I ended up here, don't feel out of placed because the staff will welcome you warmly like anyone else and be just as attentive. Enjoy!
author: Nana R.

description:
Prices are up and Quality is down since my last visit.  This used to be one of our go-to places in the Castro for an inexpensive, solid Italian meal.  Last night, $22 got me a small side Greek salad that tasted like it was made a week ago, and some rubbery shrimp and calmari drenched in what tasted like tomato sauce from a jar.  I had nothing to drink - not even a soda.

I know that commercial rent in the Castro is ridiculous, but the quality/value ratio just doesn't seem to be at Firewood any more.
author: Kraig M.

description:
I think it's the bland sauce that prevents this thin crust pizza from hittin' 5 stars, because the rest of the pizza is good. It's good in a hybrid italian/NY pizza typa way.

Food is prepared quickly, the staff is courteous and efficient, so 3 stars sums up the whole experience. 

Save this pizza for the meal you have before you board your flight. Otherwise, hit up Delfina.
author: Gabriela W.

description:
Home cooking! yum yum give me some. It's a clean well lite place. Good for 1 or 10 people.  Nice friendly staff, fast service and great food.

Love the rock shrimp tortellini or the mushroom pizza are my two favorite items.
author: Michael C.

description:
It's hidden away from the hustle and bustle (some say gay chaos) of the Castro yet close enough you can quickly get back to 2 for 1 drink specials on the main strip. Firewood Cafe is a nice place to grab a pre-drink meal with friends before a big night out.  

I had the chicken pesto pizza  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Fw7rbyKQGZEHpqFDVs6dBg?select=gJTvmbYBhRstzn41gcAiiQ#WGfbDEKaUOj4NwlK4tFCDA) and while I wished the crust was crispier and firmer in the middle, the ingredients were fresh and the flavors well-balanced. The roasted red peppers added some brightness to complement the yummy pesto. We also had a couple of sides and I liked the Caprese salad and the roasted butternut squash. Pair this with the complementary bread and olives, you have a nice meal. Oh and wine and beer of course. 

It's super causal - order at the counter and they bring it out to you. Yet it can remain somewhat intimate despite it being a fairly big and airy space. I'll be back to try the rotisserie chicken next. Firewood Cafe is worth the extra block or two walk to get away from the crowds for a little.
author: Jon L.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this restaurant. First thing to say, I love the complimentary marinated olives. This is a big plus because most of restaurants do not have anything complimentary aside bread or chips. I always wanted something different. The food at Firewood is good too.

tried the roasted chicken, chicken parmagiana (this is great), salads (cesar is ok, just standard cesar salad) and pizzas (prosciutto and pesto are my favorite ones) and the quality is about similar to other restaurants that are overpriced. One thing to point though is that I that there is no service, I think it would be better if there were waiters to refill my soda, check back or offer desserts when I am about to finish my meal.
author: Serge B.

description: When I come to here it's because it's after the gym or a support meeting & I'm too lazy to go home to cook or that the other neighborhood options just aren't doing it for me. Tonight's dinner was a special one so 25 of us unceremoniously descended upon them like locust. Love having to order & pay at the register first thereby eliminating the check split with multiple diners. Tonight I ordered the half herb rotisserie chicken with roasted new potatoes, a fail safe standard. Usually on point, tonight's bird was rather, um, dry. Though it did have all the flavor that I've come to expect from Firewood, tonight's clucker was a big miss for me. I'll certainly go back, but not when they're so slammed by a pack of hungry animals. We'll see if that makes a difference.
author: Domenic V.

description:
I've been eating here for years. For the price, this is one of my favorite places to eat in the Castro. 

Half chicken potatoes and a small green salad is my standby order. Also, if you want some dessert you really must have a piece of tiramisu , its one of the best around

I haven't tried the pasta dishes but my friends seem to like them. 

Stop in and enjoy a relaxed quick meal for a reasonable price, you shouldn't be disappointed.
author: Mark L.

description:
A cockroach, a little under 1 inch in length, walked across my table today as I waited for my lunch. I changed tables and when informed, wait staff seemed neither particularly concerned nor apologetic. They also did nothing to clean the table (wipe it down, replace the plates that were there) where the cockroach had been.

I used to like this place. Roaches are a common problem but when they're waltzing around in bright daylight, it's pretty unappetizing. Health Inspection records online also confirm a recurring "modest vermin infestation" issue.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
3.5 stars

This place was pretty good...a nice solid option in the Castro.

The space isn't all that fantastic, but the food was good quality and I appreciate the healthy options.  The price-point isn't bad and you can get a good amount of quality food for under $20 for two people if you eat family-style.  The roasted chicken and salad options seemed like the best choices on the menu.
author: Ken G.

description: Cafeteria style dining with decent affordable food. Wine selection changes regularly with semi decent wines. On a recent visit With friends we noticed that the pour has been reduced. For a $10 glass it would be nice to have more than 1/3 of a glass.
author: Aldus M.

description: We love this place and food is great for a quick meal. Don't come before 7 PM...so many children running around like monkey's on the floor without any parental guidance.
author: Bong V.

description: LOVE LOVE foods, they are awesomely tasty!! Love this neighborhood, I mean, in this amazing LGBT community!! The people who work at Firewood are so cool and friendly to the deaf community, I'm really grateful! Firewood is the one of my favorite restaurants!! :)
author: Mylene M.

description: I've eaten here a few times now, and every time it's ok, but nothing spectacular. I got the penne most recently ($15), which was a good portion size, but there was an ungodly amount of sauce and cheese. Authentic Italian pasta does not have a lot of sauce. This is definitely a typical American-Italian restaurant. There was so much sauce and it was so rich that there was a point where I said, I just can't eat anymore. If they toned down the amount of sauce and didn't put a handful of cheese on top, it actually would be a pretty decent dish and you'd be able to taste the other ingredients: peas, shiitake mushrooms, and ham.
author: Nick L.

description: So this place is alright, they take forever, the manager walks around like he can't be bothered. The line backs up with only one order taker during primetime eating hours. If you don't call ahead you could be waiting to order over half an hour. Customer service not their strung suit
author: Derek H.

description:
I went here last night for dinner and it was delicious. Though the restaurant was really busy and crowded, it didn't stops from enjoying the vibe nor finding a great place to sit.

I ordered the house tortellini with the white cream sauce. This dish never fails and I'm always quite please. They give you I believe about 13-15 large tortellini. These were cooked very well, not too soft not too firm. The chicken stuffing seemed slightly off but was quite yummy, I would have preferred more of a concrete flavor. 

Cream-based sauces are always my favorite and I feel Firewood could add to it a little more. The sauce is heavy but after 4 or 5 bites it status to get a little redundant and the rich flavor begins to overpower the dish. By no means did I not enjoy it but adding some sort of flavor to the cream sauce would be great, or even some type of vegetable, like mushrooms, would help a lot.  Also, the dish was served with delicious sourdough bread. 

Overall, great place, consistent quality, I love coming here with friends. Definitely recommend
author: Christopher S.

description:
Have been going here for decades & am comforted that it still remains here as VC tech money destroys any semblance of what makes S.F. great by replacing it with homogenized coffee shops.

Crust of Margherita pizza is perfect with just the right amount of sauce, tomatoes & basil.Garden Salad can easily be shared by two & choose the right fixings to fit your mood. Throw in a few sides (red peppers stuffed with goat cheese, feta salad, roasted potatoes) and you have a full meal without any meat. Has pasta & chicken, pork loin & salmon for carnivores.


Crowd is friendly/cruisy but tile & concrete interior can cause a high noise factor.
author: Charlie T.

description:
Their Caesar Salad are fresh and huge. I usually get one for lunch and have leftovers (which is not as good since the dressing makes the lettuce wilt.) I usually just share it with someone since it's plenty of food.

My go to order is Caesar Salad with Red Peppers, Corn and Walnuts. Basically... you can chose up to three toppings with your salad.

Another thumbs up from me is because when I ask for to go orders... they still mix my salad dressing instead of putting it on the side. I hate it when the restaurants don't mix the dressing for you and expect you to do it yourself. I understand the reasoning is so the lettuce will not wilt (see my first paragraph)... but if I'm paying for restaurant prices... then please mix it for me. Not like I will order it and not eat it for hours. Usually people order food to be eaten soon after.

Anyhoo... enough of my salad rant... 

I have also tried their pasta and roast chicken... so far so good... no complaints from me....
author: Mei C.

description:
Recommend this restaurant to everyone.

Very good value with a nice menu.

I enjoy ordering the Chicken Ceasar often.  Other menu items are good too.  Love the pizzas.  The roast chicken is delicious.  And the pastas are good and filling too.

Service and prompt and courteous.
author: Daniel P.

description:
I am so bummed about this place! We ordered Cesar salad, rotisserie chicken and penne pasta. 
The chicken was so dry that we couldn't eat it. The pasta was very bland with no flavor. The prosciutto in the pasta tasted like t was expired. The Caesar dressing was the worst I've ever had. It was sooooo fishy and lemony! Was just awful. We ended up not eating it at all and tossing it. Which is something we have never done cause we are both such fat kids! 

Come on firewood!! Step it up!
author: Lana S.

description: You can't beat that chicken. Just got a salad so can't speak to most of the menu items, but for the price I can't complain and the staff was really nice.
author: Chloe B.

description: Almost cafeteria style - one orders near the cash register, pays, and then food is delivered to your table.  Relatively quiet.  Clean well-lighted place.  The Pizza and other Italian dishes are excellent - the best around for anon-high end restaurant.  Not expensive. Great place for a very good simple meal.  They have a few desserts, which are also excellent.  There are few places in the Castro neighborhood with quality food at reasonable prices (very few places with high quality food at all.)
author: robert l.

description:
Woo hoo!!! I just paid 15 dollars for potatoes and a 1/3 of a chicken. 

Seriously bummed I had to eat lunch here.  

Totally overpriced like many food options in the Castro. 

If you aren't pressed for cash and can frivolously throw down 20 dollars on a mediocre lunch, eat here.
author: travis c.

description:
I hadn't been to this location in a few years. It was OK at best. The caesar dressing overpowering...and I asked for 'light dressing'. No olives as you order, which was a favorite.
Friendly and helpful staff.
author: Tom L.

description: The pizza is pretty good. I'm not so sure it is worth what one would pay for it, but it is a decent little restaurant in the Castro. I've come here a few times before going out for a drink. The staff is very friendly and helpful. The menu variety is pretty good.
author: James R.

description: I give a 1 star today.. Normally I would give it a 4.. Today's experience was just rudeness, I wanted chicken parmesan but without the pasta and veggies. I asked the cashier if I could just have the chicken and a side salad.. She straight out said NO... Wow there were only 5 customers in the place and now I see why... Lady learn some manners and ask your manager.. Don't make decisions on your own... Apparently you can even take an order... SMH...
author: Joseph A.

description: All time favorite place to get fettuccine. The House tortellini is awesome too. Definitely sad they closed the one in Napa.
author: Em T.

description:
I tried Firewood for the first time at a friend's birthday.  It's a good option for groups because you can be sure everyone pays their fair share since you pay up first and they bring the order to you.

I had the chicken tortellini with the Firewood sauce (blend of the marinara and white sauce).  It was really tasty.  The portions are very generous.  I also ordered the Caesar salad, and agree with other yelpers that the dressing was a little too fishy for me.  

I'm a sucker for marinated olives so I liked that they offered those complimentary while you wait.  Which speaking of, was not long at all!  Food arrived quick!  And service was friendly.  The only thing about eating here with a larger group is that the food arrives at different times, which can be a bit awkward but overall not bad.  

With a group of 15+ something's to be said when everyone was happy with their dishes!
author: Olivia D.

description: The crew here is nice.  Good food and atmosphere.  Nice artwork too.   My favorite is the capellini
author: John P.

description:
My husband and I are from out of town and were hungry for Italian food.  We weren't really sure where to go so we consulted Yelp to help us with our decision.  This place got pretty good reviews so we got in our car and drove over to the Castro district to eat here.   It's in a pretty neat neighborhood and we didn't have an issue finding a parking spot.  We did have to park a couple blocks away but that was alright since it was fun walking through the neighborhood.  

We arrived at the Firewood Cafe to find that it wasn't a sit down restaurant but that you ordered at the counter and the food was delivered to you.  This was alright but unexpected.  There was also a long line which told me that it had to be good.   

I decided at the last minute to order the special they had advertised on the board behind the cashier.  It was fettuccine with chicken and pesto along with a ceasar salad and a coke.    My husband ordered chicken parm with pasta, a ceasar salad and an iced tea.   You also get a bowl of olives to eat while you wait for your food.  

The olives were very salty but delicious.   I enjoyed my coke and my husband didn't like the tea because it tasted too much like mint and was very "herbally".  The salad came out next.  It had real ceasar dressing on it and the lettuce was very crisp and the croutons tasted good too.  The food didn't take that long to come out but the waitress put everything down in front of us and took off very quick before I realized that I didn't get what I ordered.   

I'm pretty flexible so even though I did not get the chicken pesto pasta I decided to eat what was served to me which turned out to be chicken primavera pasta.    It was one of the worst pasta dishes I have ever had.  No flavor and just hunks of unseasoned chicken mixed with broccoli.  I could hardly eat it.   My husband said that his chicken tasted like something he made at home (and he's not a good a cook).  He was also unimpressed with the capellini pasta side dish which was basically olive oil and a few tomatoes mixed with pasta.   

Overall, I expected a lot more form this place especially since our meals totaled almost $50 dollars for mediocre food and no service.  We will not be recommending this place to anyone that visits San Francisco.
author: Meredith M.

description: Mercy me, this restaurant is incredibly pricey but thet serve quite good pizzas, pasta dishes, and salads. Expect to pay 15$-20$ just for lunch. Apparently their lunch special is an entree with salad and a fountain drink for that price.... I had pasta with basil, sliced tomato, basil, and parmesan with tiny slices of bread. Portions are rather small. This is defenitely a nice restaurant to have a long, drawn out,  intimate dinner at... although I came here for lunch by myself cos I was absolutely starving, but I don't intend on returning for lunch by any means... perhaps for dinner. Mind you, you are paying the gay man's currency at this place.
author: Julian I.

description:
Coming here through the years I've observed a worrying pattern recently that gives me some concern on this casual dining place.

Prices have gone up quite a bit. Sure, everything goes up, but $15+ for the salad with chicken it's a bit too much. Then the chicken. I've tried their whole chicken a few times in the past year or two and quality has been very inconsistent, sometimes borderline nasty. I'm trying to avoid it these days. At the same time, I love the location and convenience of this place so usually you can't go wrong coming here.
author: Bartholomew F.

description:
I went back to this place - had not been here in a long time because of how small the chicken was - and much to my surprise the service was incredible. A young man named either Jed or Jay did such an amazing job - kind, careful, appropriate, friendly and made some excellent recommendations to my friends. We truly had an outstanding experience here. 

I give Jed (Jay) 5 Stars all the way - just can't get over how small the chicken got, but I guess you have to keep prices down somehow. 

Not a fan of the Sangria - but one person in our group loved it. It reminded me of a liquid cinnamon bun. Not for everyone but they were kind of enough to take it back, and comp a glass of Chianti that was quite good. BRAVO - I don't know if it changed owners or they made the best hire ever!! The Chicken is always delicious - Herb Roasted.
author: Rew C.

description: It has a great atmosphere. I got the chicken parm and it was definitely filling. The staff is super nice and the food is a great price and great quality.
author: Wendy A.

description:
Stopped in for lunch with my wife. Staff was very friendly and welcoming. I had a special - sausage & chicken jambalaya - and my wife had two sides - Caesar salad  & eggplant parmesan. They gave us yummy marinated olives to scarf while we waited, which was not very long.  My Jambalaya was fantastic. No okra, which is the way I like it. The Caesar was fresh and tasty, mostly heart of romaine. The eggplant was served sizzling in a small skillet on a board. The sauce did not bury the eggplant, which tasted great. She appreciated it as a low-carb option for a diabetic. Skillful use of herbs in both the jambalaya and the eggplant.  I appreciated that they have an unsweetened ice tea, which seems to be getting rarer.
We had the bread pudding for desert. It was good, but was served as a cube on a plate with small bowl of whipped cream. It would have been better in a bowl with a bourbon or caramel sauce. Small quibble with an otherwise wonderful meal.
We sat and wrote this review because we were surprised at the relatively low rating this great place has on Yelp.  We'll definitely be back!
author: Donald F.

description: Took a while to get my pizza, but when I did it was sooo GOOD! had chicken, roasted red peppers & freshly cut kernels of corn from a cob. Green salad was ok; they are cutting up the cucumbers & tomatoes now, used to just get a chunk of each. Liked the olives. What is giving this 5 stars is the fact that an employee repeatedly filled my iced tea & provided me with great service. Never experienced this there before. Wonderin if the Firewood Cafe is EVER going to reopen at Metreon. Luckily found great parking place today but sometimes it's an issue. Easier to park at Metreon.
author: P P.

description:
This is one of those places that you order at the counter, you are given a portable stand with a number on it and they deliver your food to the table.  

I thought the staff was courteous and thoughtful.

I ordered a sausage pizza and a coke.  The pizza is a thinner than thin crust and is quite colorful in appearance.  The pizza doesn't taste bad but it just doesn't taste as good as it looks.  The pizza is made in a brick oven and is about 12" in diameter.  Reasonable in cost.  Free refills for the soda.

It's a nice neighborhood establishment but I can't get overly excited about the place.

They need to do something to bring up the pizza a notch and it might have a greater following.
author: Robert C.

description: This is such a great place to pop in for a good, quick and delicious Italian meal!  Their pasta and side salads are really good portions and the Caesar has lots of shaved parmesan on top--YUM.  They really seem to know how to do the "casual fine dining" thing right.
author: Gabriella P.

description: Entrees and salads are fresh and absolutely delicious. Service is gracious and perfectly done- not over the top.  I will recommend this place to anyone! Great for getting a bite to eat before or after a show at the Castro Theatre.
author: Haliegh S.

description:
I used to come here when I first moved here 9 years ago - I think a bit too much as I stopped.
Walking by today I stopped in - hungry! The guys behind the counter ....patient, sincere and helpful. 
Great light on a sunny day made the place happy.....
My salad was fresh - crisp - and all my veggies we fantastic. 

Overall I sat as I was grazing asking myself 'why did I stop coming here ???'
author: Kurt K.

description: So, today is the first time I've been to Firewood cafe. The waiter that rang me up was very polite and nice. I ordered the capellini pasta and added chicken. Its so good! It was a little greasy but I'm assuming that's the olive oil in that or the cheese but it's excellent food. A little out of my price range but definitely a nice treat when you have a little extra cash. I would go back.
author: Tina M.

description: I've been here many times and have had a good experience. Tonight the salad was not crisp and fresh and the chicken was dry. Nice chardonnay
author: Tom L.

description:
I went to Firewood for a quick dinner tonight but when I arrived the line was out the door. Apparently, only one person was taking orders and he was also taking take out orders. He repeatedly answered the phone, leaving in-store customers to wait endlessly on line.

It is inexcusable for a restaurant to inconvenience customers that have made the effort to walk to their store. TERRIBLE CUSTOMER SERViCE. Shame on you, Firewood
author: Tom W.

description: Salads, pizza and pasta are all really good here. Definitely a good place to go to or pick up from. Would definitely recommend giving it a try if you haven't already.
author: Ryan P.

description:
I would go back but this place is ok , the penne pasta was a little bland but ....ok and the seafood "special" pasta was terrible. The seafood was over cooked and so was the pasta BUT that being said I have been here before and the food was better I just think that we went during a big rush at 6:30 and the chefs and servers seemed overwhelmed, 
Prices are very affordable, 2 entrees and 2 glasses of wine $43
Best to go during "off" hours
author: L V.

description: I tried the roasted chicken, it's was delicious,seasoned perfectly. I'm not sure just yet if anyone else around the corner has a roasted chicken as tasty.
author: Joe Z.

description:
I have to say that I am no stranger to this establishment and yet I remember very little about this place.  It's not because Firewood isn't memorable, but I 99% of the time drunk when I eat here.  It's just a hop skip and a jump away from both Badlands and Toad Hall, so when I need a hearty, sober me up meal, I stumble over here.  

I don't know what it is about a brick oven, but it makes any environment feel homey to me.  The oven is immediately to your left when you walk in so you get warmth when you walk in.  The service is quick, the food is reasonably priced and depending on what you get, the food is pretty tasty.  I will say that their Linguine with clams is NOT the way to go. It's just bland and one note.  Almost anything else is pretty good.  I can't really say anything about their salads because I never get them.  It just doesn't look appetizing, but that's just me.  

Anyway, drunk or sober, I think it's worth a try.  It's not like it really hurts your wallet.  I prefer going drunk, but then I prefer going everywhere drunk .
author: Aaron G.

description:
First time experience.

It's great that this place is in the Castro.
I was excited to eat here.
I didn't have a bad experience.
Service was good.
I guess I just wasn't into the food that much.
I had a pizza, but I wasn't wowed. 

Maybe I need to revisit and try something else.

Come on Firewood Cafe....WOW ME!
author: John S.

description: Nice setting, friendly staff, lots of natural light. But $19.75 for a garden salad with shrimp? That is crazy. The base salad alone was over $9, and then I think the shrimp was $7, so with tax, it was almost a $20 salad. For a to-go order! I could get an entree in a nice restaurant with table service for that amount. If prices were cheaper, I would go back, but right now it's kind of a rip-off for what you get.
author: Katie M.

description:
This place is in the Castro. Its extravagant and beautiful (like most things in this area!) Authentic Italian menu, great bites! I had the salmon, cleared the plate. I chose the Swiss chard as a side, over the roasted veggies. It was mixed with white beans, on sauteed onions. It was absolutely delicious, but the only thing I didn't like were the chunks of pork in the mix. So be prepared....or request the Swiss chard sans the piggy. 
And the chefs were so nice, they gave us a really fancy sun dried tomato, stuffed mozzarella roll on the house!
author: Cassandra E.

description: I would say, in terms of taste and quality, that the pizza was kind of on par with your average store-bought frozen pizza. Also, the dried red peppers had absolutely no heat, which I'm told is what happens when dried red peppers sit for too long and get stale.
author: Morris R.

description:
I have loved this place ever since it was born.  It seems to have the same staff since then, too.  Good food, good prices, friendly servers-- I actually know most of their names!!!   So M----, the beautiful goddess behind the front counter, has been treating me like a queen for seven years, and I know the names of all her children.
 If you don't like this Firewood location, fine, f**K off and give me your place in line, loser.
author: Madelena M.

description: I wish I came here sooner. Totally delightful, clean, with a simple menu. I has the chicken pesto pizza (thin crust, delicious rotisserie chix on top) and Caesar salad (classic, nothing special but def still good). Decently sized place that vaguely reminded me of my favorite chain in New Mexico. Will be back to indulge on more... like the tortellini. Nom nom!
author: Natasha P.

description:
This has always been a staple for me in the Castro.  There's a ton of mediocre food there since most just go for the drinks and the drunks.  Even though this is a small chain, their consistency and service has always pleased me.

My favorite thing on the menu is the House Tortellini.  Not only is it delicious, but with the Firewood Sauce on it, it's the best of the creamy and marinara choices.

Also, bonus star for their fountain drinks.  Their Coke is amazing!  The perfect blend of bubbles and flavor!  Can't wait to go back every time!
author: Andy S.

description:
A relatively uninspired dining institution in the neighborhood, and they've built successful outposts away from the Castro too, but a restaurant that kind of limps along with little change or innovation year after year.  I thought Firewood was the cat's meow when it first opened, much like other long gone chicken roasteries that popped up everywhere about a decade ago.  While little has changed at Firewood Cafe, the prices have climbed without pause and the portions have diminished and even the presentations have gone from abundance to modesty.

You enter off 18th and are in a line when crowded or right at the ordering counter when not busy.  The menu is posted on several boards that aren't easy to read or strategically located so when crowded the line can move laboriously.  In the entrance is a big pizza oven where many things are finished off along with making the flatbread pizza's.  A large roasting station with dozens of dressed fowl rotating, a salad making station and the counter where you order.  After placing your order and paying, you're given your beverage (they offer beer and wine only) you grab your silverware and napkin and go find a table or counter to eat on and wait for someone to find your number and deliver your meal.

I do like it for groups where everyone orders and pays for their own meal and no disputes about splitting the check can arise, so it is great for a group and almost always the group can find a space that can accomodate them as they wait individually for their grub.  Firewood Cafe is perfect for airports and mall's, but kind of like a missing thumb in the Castro where dining is more than airports and mall's, but they've survived a long time and there are still lines going out the door many evenings at dinner time.  It's a successful operation, but boring too.
author: Stu S.

description: I love this place for a light lunch or dinner. They make a great salad! Choose some topping, I love the free olives. Frienly people, nice food, fresh roasted chicken. Of you want more they do pasta! The salads are hige bit the pasta is targeted for a normal size appitite. If your starving they do a half of a roasted chicken over potato.
author: Richard M.

description:
I'm going to 2nd my friend Matt: Good, simple food.

For $10 I get:

1/2 Honey Dijon Chicken (with sauce on the side)
Caesar Salad (substitute for the potatoes - have to watch my boy-ish figure)
2 pieces of bread (that I give to my roommate)

Great post gym meal that you don't have to feel guilty about after.  As a bonus, the restaurant itself is comfortable with a really inviting ambiance.
author: Sean H.

description:
I'm writing to report a dismal experience I had recently with the management of Firewood Cafe.  I belong to a social group of more than 1000 women, and held a very successful Wednesday night games party for them in the back room of Firewood Cafe in December.  The staff was SO WONDERFUL on that day, and my friends ate, drank, played, and were very happy.  When I called in January to reserve a repeat, I was told NO PROBLEM! and the back room was reserved for us again on a Wednesday night in February.  I chose Wednesday specifically as an off night for most restaurants, and discussed the plan in detail with the on site manager both times.

Unfortunately, when I called to confirm the night before the party, I was told that the general manager, Vivian, had told the on site staff that I could not have the back room after all.  I would have to pay a minimum, or only have the room for an hour.  When I suggested that the night before an event  was not a reasonable time to tell me this, I was told that they forgot to write my number down so they couldn't let me know beforehand.  I was given Vivian's phone number to talk things over.

This is the bulk of my complaint, and I hope the restaurant uses it wisely.  Vivian was EXTREMELY condescending to me.  She refused to listen to my point that it was too late notice for me to change plans, and kept talking to me about their policy of no reservations of the back room unless there was a minimum.  I explained repeatedly that Had I known that, I would NOT have made the reservation, and that I would never, ever, ever, bring my group to Firewood again, but at this point it was too late.  The best she would do was say that we could have a table in the back room, but we would have to share it with other patrons.  She refused to honor the original reservation.

I want to reiterate that the staff and on site manager of Firewood were very kind and gracious.  Vivian is the one with whom we had a problem.   I certainly will keep my promise to NEVER, EVER, EVER bring my group to Firewood again.
author: peggy c.

description: Firewood isn't a bad place to grab a quick bite, especially when you're in the mood for food that just fills you up.  I wouldn't say it's the most bang for your buck especially when it's not hard to drop $20 on a plate and glass of wine.  When you're in one of the top food destinations in the world I wouldn't say that Firewood would even come close to making it on the list, so choose something different to satisfy your hunger.  That being said, when you're slightly intoxicated or plan on being, then grab some cash and head on over to this joint for a decent meal that is slightly different then what the rest of the Castro has to offer.
author: Kevin J.

description: The dish is excellent and inezpensive. Could eat there everyday!!! Try the Seafood Fettuccini
author: Eduardo G.

description:
I went tonight for dinner and it was crowded full of gay guys enjoy themselves.  I saw a bunch of local people.  My food was excellent.

shrimp tort  8.75
iced tea  2.25 (free refills)
olives - free
tax 1.09
4% surcharge   .44
total    12.55

not bad at all, I like the feeling of this location
author: Cynthia B.

description:
I'm a very easy-going person normally, and I like to talk to people. So tell me why I always get grumbles as responses from the staff here?! C'mon people! I'm like smiling and all happy go lucky.. and you just piss all over it!

But aside from the staffing... I do enjoy their food.. or well... their pizza. I've never ordered any of their other entree's but I've tried all their pizza's and their corn, tomato, and basil salad ( which i'm in love with).

Too bad they have a such a kill-joy staff though... makes me order to-go everytime!
author: amelia g.

description:
Firewood is a little bit Fast-Food, and a little bit Rock and Roll.

I say fast food, because you place your order at the counter, but really, that's where the similarities end. You are then enveloped in a warm and inviting large room with hefty wooden tables and wrought iron lamps. Such a friendly ambiance in an unassuming store front. The waiter will bring you your goods, and assuming you have chosen wisely, as I certainly had the fortune of, you will be greeted with your entree and squeal in delight. 

Mine was served in a cast iron oval skillet with rosemary roasted potatoes to dream of. So crispy outside, so tender in. Along with my garlic pan-fried shrimp and side of green and crookneck squash with yellow onion, I was munching happily with my glass of pinot noir.

A quick little dinner with nothing left desired. And easy on the wallet too!
author: Katie W.

description: I refuse to patronize any restaurant that charges ME for the health benefits of their employees. Dine here, you'll pay an additional 4%. No thanks.
author: Richard V.

description:
Chicken Ceasar 
Tortellini in white sauce 
Prosciutto pizza 


This place is a fast food Italian restaurant and I personally thought that the food, specifically the prosciutto pizza, was amazing. The tortellini with white sauce was also great and very rich. This is how I like my white sauce (that didn't sound right). It was very creamy, buttery, and thick(sounding worst). The ceasar salad caught me a little off guard. Shredded chicken and dressed very lightly. A very healthy option if you don't want to eat the heavy stuff. 

Overall, I thought it was great. The thin crust on the pizza had a nice char, not burnt, savory crust. For a guy that don't like pizza, it is worth the trip to check out. One more thing, the service is extremely fast. So, if you are in a rush, this is a great place for a quick bite.
author: jason g.

description:
Not the best food you'll ever have, not the worst.

Cheap and fast and sorta kinda healthy.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
The food is bland, although it looks pretty.  Customer service is to be desired.  Most of the menu items are overpriced for what you get, I believe.  

There are better alternatives out there.
author: Matthew E.

description:
Delicious, filling, lots of variety, WHEELCHAIR ACCESSIBLE, and not overwhelmingly loud as far as accoustics go...what's not to like?!

My favorites include their pastas (have a light appetite?  Get their kids mac'n'cheese...it's divine!) and marinated mozzarella with tomatoes and basil (why they don't just call it "insalata caprese" is beyond me!).  Also surprisingly delicious is their tiramisu...in fact, it's better than I've had in most fussy restaurants!  

The employees have always been pleasant and helpful, and the environment is bright and cheery.  You can either sit at a family-style table or individual table, which offers nice variety.

Overall, I dig this place.  I find most restaurants in the Castro over-crowded, loud and just sort of so-so as far as quality of food is concerned.  While Firewood Cafe isn't a gourmet bistro by any stretch of the imagination, nor do they make anything wildly exciting from a creativity standpoint, they do standard dishes really well and the food is consistently tasty.  Isn't that, after all, a good measure of what makes a restaurant worth visiting time after time?
author: Amy L.

description:
Never been to this location but I ate at the Airport and LOVED IT!

I asked the waiter what he really likes on the menu and he suggested the Bolognase pasta. It was pretty freaking good. I was really surprised. 

Fresh garlic, fresh basil, good ration between sauce and meat. 

Pretty freaking good and not too pricy.
author: Erica U.

description:
I am really perplexed by Firewood's 3.5 star status.  What are you all thinking?  

Now sometimes I just want pasta or tortellini and it doesn't much matter how good it is and I'm just not willing or able to boil water at my own house...okay Firewood lets go.  

But the experience is always a little disheartening.  Their tortellini are chewy and their sauces are not good, though I do recommend having them mix the marinara and cream together since it seems to compensate for the deficiencies of both a little bit.  

Given the choice I'd rather have Pasta Pomo back.
author: Luke M.

description:
I've been going to firewood for many years - mostly for lunch. I work from home these days and it is part of my shortlist of everyday lunch restaurants. It is a great place to go to when you need a quick, good value meal and don't have the time or the energy to cook.

 It has a good choice of salads, sides and entrees. Food is consistently good for the money. The service is extremely fast, so you never have to wait for your order for too long.

If only they had outdoor seating, I would go there even more often.
author: bart m.

description:
If you can find a parking space in the neighborhood this is a good place to eat for a good price.  Everything on the menu is ~$10.  I've had the pasta, salmon, and pizza, and salad.  Service is pretty good.

It really is all about the parking.
author: Bill F.

description:
I've always enjoyed Firewood, however today was a total misfire from their kitchen.  My husband, daughter and I went for lunch. Fortunately for my husband, he retreated to the Proscutto Pizza which - while not as good as he remembered - at least had some flavour. I had the worst mushroom pizza I think I've ever had, and our daughter had the kids' pepperoni pizza that was absolutely flavourless. How do you make a flavourless pepperoni pizza?  The side ceasar salad was never great at Firewood, and it remained not great today. Its lack of greatness, however, was emphasized by the horridness of the entrees.

After years of occassional dining at Firewood, I can only think that they've changed chefs, and the new chef hasn't adjusted to the menu - or doesn't bother to taste and season his/her food.

If I'm ever to return, it will either be rock shrimp tortollini or roast chicken. Stick with what you know is good.
author: Scott B.

description: this place is off the hook. this place is hella good i love it i would definently come back to this place. I came from sanjose with 2 friends and visiting a friend. I had the seafood linguine it was awesome my friend had linguini alfredo and a house tortellini we all liked it.
author: Kenny P.

description:
Since I've worked in the castro since the early 90's....I've come here a lot.

I don't think it's fair to compare it to a non-chain restaurant, so I'm not going to. At a non chain restaurant you can't get a salad, half a roasted chicken, and a pint of beer for $18. 

The staff are always courteous and friendly. The food comes reasonably quick, which is important because I've always got less than 45 minutes to order, eat, and get back to work. 

The house tortellini in garlic cream sauce is rich, sinful and probably laden with calories and fat and I love it, and feel that glutton nausea after I eat it, and I'm cool with that because I occasionally find that satisfying, like many Americans...They also have things like grilled zucchini, and gigantic salads with many toppings available. 

On the healthier side I get the rotisserie chicken, and a salad in place of the potatoes. And their beer is Sierra Nevada (and a couple other brands)...it's nice when at a chain you can get a quality beer, rather than a budweiser or heinekin. 

There are three separate dining areas...two well lit, the one in the middle is darker and I usually hide there during my lunch hour, and read the newspapers they provide. There is plenty of seating, so you can go with quite a group of people and sit together, no reservations necessary.

So if you're looking for fast, decent, not expensive, no frills dining in the Castro, this is a good place to go.
author: Nick M.

description:
This place is real nice if you take it for what it is. I always pass through there and today stopped for take out for the first time. It's kind of Italian fast food, but made when you order and the quality is higher than you'd expect. 

The service was extremely friendly. I kind of didn't know what to order because it was my first time and the cashier let me take all the time I needed to make up my mind (and it took me some). She helped me pick - and also warned me that some dish has sausage and suggested to change it to chicken for me. 

I waited about 10 minutes for the food to be ready, and I was offered a glass of water while waiting. 

When I got home the food was very nice, I had the salmon with potatoes and the rigatoni with chicken instead of sausage - and both were nice and tasty. 

A good solution for TA while in a hurry, I also wouldn't mind sitting there - the place looks clean, the design and the atmosphere are nice, check it out if you are locals.
author: Too M.

description: Had a late lunch here on a Thursday after arriving at SFO and taking a drive to Twin Peaks! The Seafood Linguine was awesome ... Spicy, but cooked well! Hubster had the sausage pizza and The Kid had the pepperoni pizza - both dishes got thumbs up! Service was good.
author: Mary R.

description:
It seems kind of expensive for what it is but it is always pretty good food.  The salads are big and seem pretty fresh, the pasta is good too.  Oh and the margarita pizza is awesome too.  And I love that they always have green olive to snack on before the food comes.  The servers are polite, the guy with red hair is super friendly and always checks in on everyone.
If I'm too lazy to make a quick salad but I want something light, I'll usually walk the few blocks down here.
author: Jonathan T.

description:
i always forget this place is there. cause its the only restaurant in castro that doesn't have a herd of sassy south east asian boys waiting the tables. 

i had the pasta more specifically the capellini. for under $10 this dish was a great size and delicious. my partner had the half chicken and friends had pizzas, everything were great. i really like the simple menue. 

super friendly people work there. smiles, polite and there was a little language barrier, but the woman at register and man clearing tables both attempted to strike up a conversation but mostly just smiled a lot. 

p.s. it was kinda empty i hope it stays around cause its a nice option in castro, it dosnt seem to fit in the neighborhood. feels very strip mall. but anyway i hope they stay around.
author: Satoshi K.

description:
Really? Is it too hard to ask a question to the manager and get a decent response?

Here's what happened: I called in and ordered the Prociutto pizza for pick up (looking forward to the 'wood fired' pizza experience from them) and they said it would be ready in 10 minutes. I got there at 11 minutes. (The sales receipt reflects this.)  I started walking out the door and turned back and said, was this just fired?  It doesn't seem very hot.  They said yes.  I got home (2 blocks away) and I should have went with my gut instinct.  The pizza crust was not even warm, let alone hot.  Granted, I knew the arugula on the pizza would not be warm, but the pizza crust, should have been hot and crispy, but rather, was cold and chewy.  Unacceptable in my view, and ok, I'll just call and inquire.  

The response --  is what prompted this review.

Firstly, the same woman who took my order, and rung up my order, was now basically saying she couldn't do anything for me. (Or at least that's what I gathered as her accent was extremely hard to understand, and I don't speak Spanish.)  Secondly, I asked for her manager.  He came on the phone, and -- though a little bit better to understand, I couldnt catch his name, and when I proceeded to tell him about my experience, he wasn't prepared to do anything about it.  He said it was my fault as I got there not at 10 minutes. (I got there at 11 minutes, and he agreed to that.) He also said it was raining outside.  What does THAT have to do with serving me a cold pizza?  I advised him I did use their 30% off coupon for Tuesdays in March, but should I get 30% -- or lower -- food quality?  Or 30% lower in service?  I asked him how he wanted to rectify the situation (assuming he would provide a coupon for a free pizza) and he said he could provide a 25% off coupon.  I stated that that wasn't acceptable and that I'd be by for a full refund.  And I'd be happy to drop off the uneaten cold pizza for him if he'd like.

Truth be told, this wasn't the first negative customer experience I've had here, and for me that's truly disappointing.  Their penne pasta dish with prociutto and peas and shitake mushrooms is fantastic, but everything else I've had, including the service, has been a diasappointment.  

I hope things turn around here, but at the moment I'm not sure I care, as I'm not sure I'll be back.  Truth be told, I think I'll give them one more shot, -- as I want restuarants to succeed in my neighborhood -- not fail --  but for all of you, spending your hard earned money, just keep this review in mind if you step in there.

Cheers.
author: Nicole O.

description: I liked this "gourmand vs. cafeteria" establishment enough to go back a second time during my visit to S.F. Everything is cooked to order, it seems. The house tortellini with marinara was yummy, cooked al dente. The olives-while-you-wait was a nice touch and the bussing staff was eager to please and always made sure the water glasses were filled. Prices were reasonable, much more so that a sit-down restaurant in the area.
author: Michael G.

description:
Firewood is a good standard in the Castro.  I would have given them 3 stars, but it's food that you can eat on restricted diets (Gluten-free and Paleo).  That adds a point from me any day!

I am a fan of their salmon and chicken.  They usually have a chicken special that's really good.  Their orange-mint chicken was particularly good.  Also, their swiss-chard side is amazing.

Yes...you pay a bit more here.  However it truly is a healthier option after drinking in the Castro!
author: Eric S.

description:
Portions are generally great. However, the half roasted chicken we got this past Friday must've come from a starved chicken. Not much meat, but it came with tons of roasted potatoes. 
The pizza we got was just ok. Nothing special. 
Service was adequate and ambiance was chilled.
author: teatzar s.

description:
Say you're in the Castro to shop, hang out or to meet a new "friend".....grab a quick meal at Firewood!!!

Food = 4.0.  I typically get the garden salad with chicken or salmon.  The portions are huge and the ingredients are very fresh.  When I want something a little more caloric, I go for the pastas, the roast chicken or one of the pizzas.  The tortellini is especially yummers.

Service = 3.5.  Okay....so you order at the counter and then grab your utensils and wait at your table with a number.  So what?!  Who cares!? The staff brings out the food quick and they are really nice.  It's not Gary Danko.  It's Firewood!!!!

Atmosphere = 4.0.  Casual neighborhood dining at its best!

PS - I really hope the location in the Metreon re-opens soon!
author: Eddie L.

description:
I wish I could give this 3 1/2 stars, but since I can't I can only give it three. (Honestly the extra half is just based on the company I was with there, so they kind of don't deserve it.)

They have a varied menu of pasta, meat and salads and it's pretty good for the money.  You go up and order and they bring it to your table.  

Fine dining?  No.  Simple?  Yes.  

I don't go here often, but I am sure I will go again.
author: Sean O.

description:
One Sunday I got out of Glide church, and I had a craving for Itallian pasta. I just kept heading up Market street till I arrived at my old neighborhood: the Castro. I just asked the locals, in the street where could I find a good meal. Actually a nice police officer recommended Firehouse. 
My daughter and I both ordered tortellini. I had the house version with a mixed red and white sauce. She ordered a seafood version. We loved our orders. We also noticed they made a simple, rustic chicken and potatoes. It only cost $8 for each of our pastas. If we had the same meal say at the warf, or downtown we would have paid 2-3 times as much. 
After our meal, we  walked over to the converted photo studio of Harvey Milk, to find out about gay rights. It was a delightful day out. P.S parking on Sunday is pretty  much where your heart desires!!!
author: elizabeth a.

description:
I went here for the first time with some coworkers after a community service event. We probably missed the lunch rush since we got there around 2PM.  So many things on the menu caught my eye. I wanted to order capellini, roasted chicken w/potatoes, cesar salad with chicken... pizzas....so hard to decide! But I went for a side cesar salad and margarita pizza (did I spell that right?).  

I originally ordered the pizza so I can take it home for dinner, but it was so good that I ate the whole thing....including my cesar salad. I'm sure to be back when I'm in the area. I really want to try those potatoes. They look so good!

Reasonably priced, good food.  Friendly people behind the counter.  I can see myself getting frustrated looking for parking though.
author: Dawn D.

description:
I went here a few times in the pat years and was underwhelmed... but last night we had a few opinionated people in the group and decided that this would be a good compromise.

Honestly, the pizzas were outstanding last night... the servers were friendly and the sodas were icy cold and it was just perfect.

The salad was a bit... regular... so not a five-star experience. But a solid four. Will be going back again when in the neighborhood, for certain.
author: Sean B.

description: Yum. This place is superb. I didn't think much of the place when it was suggested that we grab take out. Seeing as it looked like a version of Amici's pizza. We grabbed a margarita pizza, half of the herb roasted chicken and a side salad to go. The line was out the door. The food was about a 10 minute wait which was faster than some places. The pizza was awesome. The tomato sauce was perfect not super heavy. Fresh slices of tomato made it even better. The chicken was awesome. Tender white meat literally fell off the bone. The side salad wasn't anything to write home about but rounded off the meal. Great place to grab take out if you are craving good pizza and some awesome chicken.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: Pretty decent pizza, loved the roasted chicken!
author: Bren Y.

description:
If you are looking for a quick sit-down/take-out food option, without a fast-food feel, I suggest the Firewood Cafe.  Yes, this is a small Nor-Cal chain restaurant, which offers Californian/Mediterranean cuisine that is comparable to a Fuzio's or Pasta Pomodoro.  In a food city like SF, I'd say that the food is consistently average and it won't break your budget (with most main dishes - pasta, 1/2 pizza, salad, 1/2 chicken...) under 15 (incl/non-alcoholic beverage and tax).  The 1/2 rotisserie chicken was tasty and a good portion size for 2 people and the rigatoni was a large serving that could be split between 2 diners, as well.  I've also tried the pepperoni pizza at the SFO location and it is consistently good (and from what I've heard from other diners at the Castro location, if equivalent to the Castro pizza - thin crust, light on sauce, lots of cheese and pepperoni).

Like other reviewers, I don't recommend the wine...I ordered a pinot grigio and ended up tossing 3/4 of my glass of wine away.  It was awful!  As for the service, very basic, order at the front and take a number and a server will find your table when the food is ready.

The space at Castro is large with front room seating and a back room area with booths and more seating.  Parking in THIS area is hit or miss, especially when raining.  Yet, there is usually ample parking on Eureka street several blocks away.  Public transportation is quite convenient, as this is near the underground SF Muni station.

All in all my bill for 2 people ( chicken, rigatoni and pinot grigio) with service charge, tax and tips - 32.55
author: Hiromi N.

description: I eat here more that I should. Comfort food. I could make almost everything myself, but sometimes I want somebody else to prep the creamy pasta sauce so I don't feel guilty about it.
author: Mark P.

description: Rock shrimp Tortellini is soo good with the firewood sauce. The margherita pizza is simply delicious. Love the salads with choice of toppings.
author: EmmettsGuRL C.

description:
Great choice of toppings for their salads, quick service, quality food make this relatively reasonably priced cafeteria-type restaurant a favorite place for lunch.  There's always been plenty of tables to choose from, and the food-runners are pleasant and haven't missed me yet.

Not much atmosphere, and the salads are so good that I haven't ventured into the other items on their limited menu.   It's a good place, and maybe I'll find that it's even better... if I can make myself try some new stuff.
author: Galen W.

description:
I really want to like Firewood... I like their menu, the space, and the location but it's just not coming together.

THE HOUSE WINE TASTES LIKE ASS. EVERYTHING IS TOO SALTY. THE WORKERS HAVE NO CLUE WHAT THEY'RE DOING. 

The olives are pretty good. Not like you made them but whatever. Also no servers and when you try to get your own water, they just stare at you quizzically and take your glass. So confusing! I'll be the first to admit I'm a ditz with a passive aggressive streak so maybe I should have been a little more proactive and voiced my concerns instead of spitting my vitriol on the internet. I guess that's why I love yelp so much. Also, I'd have to direct my frustration and anger on friends and family. They don't deserve that.

My friend got the pizza and said it was good. Meh. It looked aiit. 

Special props for the table of hot cops next to us that later discreetly asked my friend to put out her joint during the Castro Halloween madness.  Does San Francisco's Finest have one of those beefcake calendars?
author: dr S.

description:
_Ambience_: Nice natural lighting. Very airy feel. Separate rooms.

_Noise_: Can get loud when large parties take up the entire space.

_Food_: I can only go by what I've ordered: Vegetarian Ravioli (the one with the eggplant and peppers). Of the 3 sauces they offer, I chose the white wine sauce. I thought the sauce was too sweet -- as if the cook used sugar instead of salt. I'm pretty forgiving, so I would go back again, even though I did not finish my dish. And, I will order a side salad, which I forgot to do.

Husband had the salmon, which came in a hot cast-iron serving dish. I did not try his salmon, but I did try his potatoes and the Swiss chard. The potatoes were very well-seasoned; I'm not much of a Swiss chard fan, so I did not try any more than a bite.

If I liked olives, I'd be squealing in delight at the way they offer little plates of them upon request. 

You do have to remember to get your utensils and napkins after you leave the counter and before you sit down.
author: Ruiqiu K.

description: Excellent food and the friendliest people I've met yet in San Francisco! Highly recommended!
author: Adam S.

description: Got a tip on this place from our wine tour driver and decided to jump on the metro and try it out.  St. Patties in the Castro District, so it was entertaining just getting there.  At any rate, the relaxed atmosphere was very welcoming.  We ordered the Chicken Pesto Pizza and a side of acorn squash for something on the healthy side and both were very tasty.  I would like to go back and sample some of the other menu items.  Two thumbs up.
author: Dana M.

description:
I've been going to Firewood since it opened. Must be 10 years.  But I'm seriously over this spot. They are just not trying anymore.
I typically pick up one of their rotisserie chicken, to go.  This last chicken $15.95 and was overcooked and dry.  If I wanted overcooked, dry chicken, I would make it myself for $8, or walk across the street to Delano's Supermarket. This is about the third time in a row, over a two month period.
author: Adam R.

description: Nothing impressive but it's good food. I wasn't thrilled when my friend and I found out that 1 pizza isn't really enough to share between two people so we got another pizza after consuming the first. The cashier was nice and helped us decide. The pizza was...pizza. Not filling but tasty. I probably would have gotten more for my money at the other pizza places on Castro. The acoustics in here are very loud as well so that was a downside. Though, it is  a nicer place to eat than the other pizza places.
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
This place is convenient, predictable, reliable, and clean. The food is well prepared and fresh.  I took a friend for a later lunch and we both enjoyed as we sat in the spacious and openness of the restaurant. You don't feel rushed. The people that come and go all seem to enjoy the food (not many empty plates left) and there is a real comfort to the place.

If you're looking for somewhere to get some good, quality, pasta, salad, fire(wood) cooked fresh food, eat here!

Oh, and their ice tea is great, it's raspberry flavored.
author: Mark M.

description: Quick food but far from fast food. Great quality food at very reasonable prices, especially for a place in the Castro.
author: Tracy P.

description:
I'm aware that Firewood serves things other than their fantastic, customizable salads, I just don't care.

This place is Salad. Heaven.  When I was a wee gay, it was at Firewood that I learned that you could put candied nuts on salads.  WHAT?!
