Apparently it's still not widely known, as every time I make a salad and put a candied pecan or walnut on it, people act.. well, like I did the first time I ate at Firewood.  But ultimately, it's the freshly-grilled rotisserie chicken that seals the deal.

Go hungry - the salads are huge, the prices are great, and you'll have plenty of mojo to go hit the Castro afterward without feeling like you became a bear in the process.  And in a city like San Francisco, where everything food/bar/club related is subject to the caprice of gay fussiness, the fact that Firewood has been around for 10+ years is really all you need to know.
author: Michael T.

description:
I love eating at Firewood Cafe after yoga class, while I'm working (using their free wi-fi!), or whenever I'm in the mood for good pasta and a good chat with a good friend.

First off, their free olives deserve their own paragraph-length tribute. As I'm writing this, I've realized I judge many restaurants by their olives...I love olives. Firewood has big, firm green ones; soft, wrinkly brown ones; hard, sweet little ones. And they're free!!! I eat as many little bowls as they'll give me.

I usually get the rock shrimp tortellini with green onions, shallots and red bell pepper or the penne tossed in a white wine cream sauce with prosciutto, shiitake mushrooms and sweet peas. If I'm really hungry, like last night, I'll order a side caesar. Their portions are generous, so I usually have leftovers.

I like how airy and sunny the place is, and I'll admit to shazaming quite a few of the catchy pop songs they play. if it were in my 'hood, I would eat here every day.
author: Ali W.

description: The restaurant is a convenient location, the staff is friendly, and the prices seem okay aside from beverages which are overpriced in my opinion. But the food just wasn't that good. The restaurant is seat yourself and was clean and organized. The interior seemed a little dated and the space was organized strangely, but the bar seating at the front window is nice. The portion size of the food was very large but again, it just wasn't that good in my opinion. Everything tasted bland and had little flavor.  I felt I wasted my money going there.
author: L. A.

description: I like the food here but they are a bit inflexible about sides and stuff.  The acoustics here are very poor and it's loud just in case you have problems hearing in social situations. Still, I do like their take on grilled beets (served cold) and that was enough to get me inside Firewood on a recent, rare Castro visit (albeit only because Nirvana had closed its doors for good).
author: Jim G.

description:
YUMMERS TO THE TUMMERZ!!

I've never had a bad meal here.  Food is always good here and the quality is consistent.  Service is on par with the casual atmosphere.  They serve one of the best salads in the city.
author: Eric B.

description:
Reasonable prices and a nice sit down space lured me into this spot around the corner from the office. The food was decent, nothing to write home about. 

The pizza's crust wasn't quite there, thin but not crispy. The mushrooms were overwhelmed by the heavy dose of caramelized onions. The salad was average, but perhaps my toppings choices weren't ideal.
author: Elise B.

description: I was a regular here but after being away for two years I decided to try it again. Always had the salad with chicken and three fixins. Very dissapointed. First of all- what happened to the free olives? The chicken on the salad used to be pieces of roasted chicken, this time it was a flat piece of heated chicken- looked and tasted like hot car board. For almost $14 a salad, they could have done better.
author: Mark E.

description:
Coffee house style pizza place.  Queue up, order food, pay, take a number, sit.  Yet the prices are at the level for a sit-down, server restaurant.  The girl at the register had such a dead look on her face that it was actually unnerving.  

I came from out of town to meet my two girlfriends for dinner here on 6/20/12.  We had the 1/2 roast chicken, mushroom pizza, and shrimp tortellini w/ white sauce.  All were good enough to eat w/o complaint.  

It just wasn't good enough to make a special trip.  Too many other restaurants for the money, food, and atmosphere that I won't be coming back.
author: crystal s.

description: Usually am here every Sunday after church its a great place to be around that time. My room mate and I get the mac and cheese off the kids menu that is to die for. They have been so accommodating with our big group(MCCSF). You can come with a big group because they take individual orders up at the front. Food comes out nice and hot and just they way you want it. We have also had the soup and the chicken all so yummy.
author: Davey B.

description: A neighborhood joint offering salads, pizza, pasta, and Dijon-honey glazed or herb-rubbed rotisserie chicken, available half or whole, served with outstanding fire-roasted new potatoes. The mushroom pizza, baked in a wood-fired oven, combines sauteed shiitake, oyster, and crimini mushrooms with caramelized onions, is very tasty but has a crust thinner than I prefer. Pastas are ordinary, and the create-it-yourself salad options are better at Pluto's. Go on a Monday or Tuesday, when everything on the menu is 20% off.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
I'm a huge Firewood fan. I come here at least once a week. I am in love with their rock shrimp tortellini! Their pizzas are amazing, and I've only had their salads a few times, but they have always been good.

Their prices are very reasonable and they do well with to-go orders if you aren't looking to dine in! I love living in the neighborhood because every now and then I get a coupon for a free pizza with entree purchase. Totally a great deal! Worth checking out, and you'd never guess they were a chain.
author: Ryan B.

description:
Peter and I go here at least once a week. I'm surprised that I haven't written them up yet! 

Martha, the woman who usually takes our order is always there with a smile on her face. Don't let the smile fool you though, she's totally got it in her to be a HUGE bitch! I should know, she unleashed it on me once. However, ever since then she's been on her best behavior. 

The food is yum. Their salads are great, their pizza is yum, and their pasta is pretty good, though not the best. It's a great pre-tennis dinner. Not too filling if you share everything!
author: Guy F.

description:
good food, but the employees treat you horribly if you bring in a child. even if your child sits quietly and eats adult food. 

too catty for my liking.
author: SF U.

description:
Following up Michael Bauer's Friday columns on good pizza, I decided to give this place a chance.  The mushroom pizza looked inviting, so I decided to order one and sit and read my book while waiting. The place wasn't packed, but I was eating in early evening after working all day, so there was plenty of seating.  I will observe that at around 6:30 pm, the place really started filing up. 

The restaurant is almost bizzare in the city, it really is right out of the suburbs.  You place your order, they give you a number, you fetch your own utensils and find a place to plop down. They bring you your food and certainly don't offer you chili flakes or parmesean, what you see is what you get. 

The pizza was tasty, although nothing special. The three kinds of mushrooms were good, but there weren't that many to be found.  The carmelized onions, while great, were almost over kill.  The sauce was actually very very good (perhaps the marguerita pizza would have been better?) but the crust was really lacking.  This place could spice things up by perhaps having whole wheat or cornmeal crusts. 

All in all, an easy experience.  I think my bill was $11 and I had more than enough pizza for two women (do not try to split with your boyfriend or you will be sorry).  I do want to return and try the large dinner salads that many people around me seemed to be enjoying.  All and all a pleasurable cheap dining experience in the Stro.
author: Claire C.

description: I am not a frequent (nor super picky) yelper, but the chicken here was nasty.  I was starving after a long stairway walk in San Francisco and hunger could not make this food taste good.  You shouldn't be able to be a restaurant in the heart of San Francisco and make food this poorly.
author: M H.

description:
MMMMMMMM, tortellini with firewood sauce!

Here or to go, you have to know, will be quick and consistent.
author: Mike K.

description: Ok so u don't get drink refills and I received my entree before my soup.
author: Kevin S.

description:
I'd put this in the same category of eatery as Pasta Pomodoro: a good utility food stop, with maybe a bit less flair.

I don't think Firewood's chicken is necessarily their best selling point. It's okay, but in my experience, just a tad greasy (also, I am a cheap bastard and the discount muto-chickens at Costco have destroyed my ability to buy them anywhere else)

I usually order pasta, salad, of something from of their cold antipasti selection. I like coming here with friends because you just order and have a seat, which just seems less complicated than more service-oriented restaurant dining.
author: Karsten P.

description:
I've been landing on this fire-roasted oven for eight years now. Lately though, they have been skimiping on their portions, and what the fock! They no longer serve complimentary olives at each table, which was half the reason for going here!

Anyway the pizzas, the herb-roasted chicken, and the pastas all have award-winning qualities, and they are priced a little too high.   Their Firewood sides are also appealing, particularly the fire-roasted beets. Set your whole body straight for an entire week with an order of those beets!  

You can eat healthy here, but to do so, you may have to stick to the monstrous salads.   Make sure to add three extra ingredients to your salad for free!

Be creative and try some combos too.  When the moon hits your eye, grab the Italian sausage pizza and add prosciutto to it for a $14 pizza pie.  Add beets to your salad and watch them stain everything purple, including your clothes.  

Expect to stand in line and collect cobwebs though, as the cashiers are painfully slow, and they never seem to realize it, no matter how many times you complain to the managers. They give local merchants like me a 10% discount, which really attracts me any day of the week.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Burnt out staff,  low-grade lunch meat on the pizza, dried out Chicken - what more can one want. 

Thought it was just a bad night when I ordered the Ham & Pineapple pizza special.  What I received was a pizza with cheap ham lunch meat and canned pineapple.  Another night I tried the Prosciutto pizza.  The meat was laid on top cold as an after thought.

So many better options in the Castro.
author: Neal P.

description:
My record is eating here 3 nights in a row.

The Caesar Salad can't be beat!  The slight taste of the anchovies makes it a legit Caesar - Just ask Alexis Stewart!

The Prosciutto Pizza is another of my all time favorites.

I can't count the number of times I've been here and I haven't had one bad experience.  In fact...I know where I'm going for dinner tonight.
author: Stacy Y.

description: I know, I know. I shouldn't like a chain restaurant but Firewood is going to have to be an exception to that rule. It isn't the be all and end all of SF dining experiences but I do really enjoy their salads. It's my comfort food when I am in town. You can pick and choose from many delicious toppings (roast chicken, beets, corn, etc.) and the ingredients are always fresh. I also enjoy the casual dining approach at the place with the communal table in the middle, people easily exchanging greetings. When I used to live in the neighborhood, it was a must on a weekly basis. Oh and the price? Very reasonable.
author: Erin W.

description:
Ick. Seriously, this neighborhood is SORELY lacking in good food options... our Guncle agrees, btw.

I ordered food to go and the food was edible (amazing how hungry you get after 8 hours on your feet!) --- the pizza was soggy and the cheese wasn't the least bit crispy or melted (i'd take a margharita pizza from Pazzia ANY day) The feta tomato pepper salad was fine (for $4 cheep though) but for a grand total of $26, I should have just ordered from Askew grill instead! 

Skip it.
author: Sf Momm Y.

description: I went here long ago, before I moved to the Castro even... and I haven't been back... there are just better options for food, I was not impressed, nothing memorable at all...
author: Aaron W.

description:
Delicious if you enjoy COCKROACHES.

It's time Firewood Cafe in the Castro cleaned up its act.  I stopped eating here a few years ago because they couldn't seem to get the flies under control.  I drew the line when I found one in my food.  

But hope springs eternal... Today I returned with a friend for lunch.  Halfway through I forked out a cockroach.

I returned my food to a very apologetic cashier.  She promptly issued a credit for exactly 1/2 our bill.  A bit surprised, I asked why not a full refund.  Silly me... "Because the roach was only in ONE salad."  

Firewood isn't hurting for business - it's been around for years and has nice ambiance for casual dining.  And the food is actually pretty good - when there aren't bugs in it.  Its management, however, could use some common-sense lessons in customer service and health management.  Perhaps my letter to the San Francisco Department of Public Health will help them along.
author: Z D.

description:
I agree with a few others here. For about 6-months last year the food quality seemed to drop a bit. Lately though, its been back up to its normal exceptional quality. They've rotated some staff and I can't help but wonder if that had something to do with it. 

The Metreon location always seemed to be about just churning out customers but the Castro one has a very neighborhood feel. I love how they rotate art work on the walls. 

Ever since the small renovation, things have been back on par with what I've come to expect from the place. The old style was just fine IMHO but I guess nothing wrong with updating. Overall, its a great place to eat. I'm here often and they even make specials not currently on the menu for me at times. 

Simple menu, good food, good prices, in an enjoyable environment. 

They also added free wifi as well.
author: Moby D.

description: Firewood is an always dependable option for lunch or dinner.  It has a great selection of thin crusted piazzas cooked in wood-fired oven, and the roasted chicken with rosemary tomatoes are really good.  The other pasta items aside from linguini and clam are a bit lame, but I don't normally go there for an Italian feast ... a good reliable place when I'm in the area.
author: S. I.

description:
Firewood is great if you want your salad to be your main course.  The toppings and dressing are a step above what you would find at a salad bar, but about the same price as what you would pay at Whole Foods or at a cafeteria.  The lines are usually short and it's not difficult to find seating.  

It's a good place to meet up on a summer afternoon and catch up with friends.  Nothing fancy, just good conversation.  The Metreon location has a completely different feel.  I don't think of it as the same restaurant so I have stayed away.
author: CW P.

description:
I've never been, but they get three stars just for smelling incredible as I walk by.
*Update* Now that I've been there, it still gets three stars.  My friend's pizza was dry, my pasta dish with peas and mushrooms was perfectly acceptable but nothing to write home about.  I'll give them another try for the fabled enormous salads, though -- seems like a great deal, since you get to pick three toppings and they are served in a bowl you could soak your head in.
author: Jude F.

description: Everyone who works here is extremely friendly, the food is very consistant and good, prices are good, cozy sunny atmosphere.  Its a great lunch spot!  Plus they offer weekly coupons that are a great deal if you sign up for their mailing list!
author: Lucille J.

description: For a place where you ordered at the counter and things were pretty casual, they served damn good food.  I had a half chicken with honey-dijon glaze which was lovely and far more than I could possibly eat.  The roast potatoes on the side were good, too.  However, I wish I had ordered the rock shrimp tortellini.  I tried one from my friend's order and it was fabu.  OMG, so good.  The baked rigatoni, which my other friend got, was also good, if not amazing.  Definitely a place worth trying.
author: Robin K.

description:
When I came here, I had a hard time choosing an item from the menu, mostly because nothing from the selection seemed to "pop."  I found myself searching the restaurant looking for something charming, but it failed to deliver any message to me this restaurant offered something unique or special.  

Comfortable seating area in the back.  Food was decent.  I ordered the salmon.  The fish was a tad dry.  The meal came with with potatoes (It's hard to screw up on potatoes).

Maybe their salads/pizzas are tastier?
author: Naseem E.

description:
Firewood, at least to me, is a word that evokes hearty and flavorful food, full of smokey goodness and rich spices.

Sadly, Firewood Cafe does not live up to its name.  Don't get me wrong -- it wasn't bad, but I wasn't particularly impressed.

I had the kids' portion of the rosemary chicken, which they were kind enough to upcharge for $1 to white meat only, but there wasn't much to brag about.

This is a nice little place with some character and charm, but you'd be better off looking elsewhere if you're looking for really good food.
author: Joel F.

description:
I'm always on the lookout for nice little Italian-type places, and Firewood definitely fits this bill.  It's got rustic decor in the way of huge tables, a nice open front room, a small cozy back section, and a counter up front where you get to see the food go out.  This, incidentally, was a fantastic tool in helping me decide what to order.

Portion size at Firewood is impressive, to say the least.  The salads I saw going out looked as if they each emptied out someone's garden.  But as I had been a Very Good Girl that day, the salads were not for me.  Instead, I opted for the veggie tortellini in marinara sauce.  A dozen, larger-than-normal dumplings of happiness were placed before me, accompanied by two hunks of bread and smothered in a very thick marinara.  The tortellini themselves were very flavorful, and I got hints of each of the ingredients as I was eating them.  I found that the parmesan within made them a little salty, but other than that they were spot on.  The pasta was a very rich, yellowy color and a very thick, chewy (but not too chewy!) consistency, and the marinara sauce wasn't oily at all.  I am fairly positive it consisted of little more than pureed tomato, and was thick enough to sit on my fork all on its own.  If you don't find this appealing, my apologies - you're missing out.  The bread was hearty, white, and just like mother used to buy from the reputable Italian bakery.  For bonus awesome, get the corn, tomato, and basil side salad.  It's extra garlicky, but that makes it extra fun!  My boyfriend opted for the salmon entree, and while he found the potatoes a teensy bit dry on their own, he said the rest of it was excellent.  He even went a little nuts over their steamed veggie side, and he's normally a very meatypotatoey type of guy.

The service, while minimal, was friendly, and I like how there are complimentary bowls of olives waiting to be snatched up at the counter along with your silverware.  These olives are, incidentally, also very good.  I was there with a large group, which was accommodated nicely, and a friend of mine arrived late and needed to grab something to go.  They helped her out with that, and put a rush on it so she could leave with the rest of us.  I had a good, solid experience.  I wouldn't say "no-frills," but there are just enough frills to make you feel special.  Special, and somewhat like the Almighty Conquerer of Pasta.  But that might just be me.
author: Becca S.

description:
I can see why this place is so popular with the Castro set: it has just a little something for everyone in a neighborhood that doesn't exactly aspire to the heights of culinary excellence. (I can say that, I live there.) 

For the lettuce-raging herbivore, Firewood's salads are simply monstrous and offer enough options to customize to your cellulose-craving heart's content. The pastas really aren't so great, but not that bad either... the cream sauce is rich and salty enough to wash down the two (ok, I'm lying, six) Stoli cosmos you just guzzled over at the Badlands. In between are some decent roasted chickens and pizzas. 

Nothing out of this world, but for the price, pleasantly solid.
author: Aaron L.

description:
The decor is great, the menu impressive but the actual food leaves a lot to be desired. Tiny portions of entrees, salads that, while large, lack sufficient amounts of chicken or heartiness to be filling. And the half chicken seems to be all bones and skin. The pasta dishes would make my Sicilian grandmother roll over in her grave and the pizza is just sad. Service is sorely lacking. Last friday the rest of my group was served before me, turns out they lost my order! And the one food runner barely had time to hear my plea to track down my dinner!

Save your money, go to Chow or Fuzio.
author: Timoteo K.

description: This place has really good food, casual setting always with lots of seating.
author: DE B.

description:
If you want to pick up something quick or have a date with a person you only kinda like, then Firewood is your place. 

The pasta is great (get the Firewood sauce), prosciutto pizza is good, chicken is moist and the salads are huge (get the dressing on the side). The only downside is they have communal olives on the tables, which seems gross to me...
author: Paige B.

description:
Hey Neighbor!

Casual place; reasonably-priced; reliable, basic foodstuff.  Great for lunch.  Meal for two with a couple glasses of wine less than $40.  Go back?  Yes. (Take-out too.)

Place/Service: the Castro location is much nicer than the one in the Metreon -- high ceilings, cheery colors, interesting layout with different "rooms," rotation of art by local artists.  I like the front window bar where you can watch the local fauna saunter by on 18th St. or the back room up a few steps with the skylights and booths.  It can get a bit noisy since it's all solid surfaces.  You order at the counter and the food is brought to the table.  Usually efficient, but can be slow when busy.  Orders don't always come to the table at the same time which is awkward when there are a few of you -- especially if you have proper manners and wait for your dining mates to all have food before starting to eat.  

Food:  the simple and short menu is great.  For the salads you can pick 3 different toppings... my fav combination is the garden salad with caramelized onions, glazed walnuts and granny smith apples.  You can add roasted chicken too, and ask for the dressing -- great herb vinaigrette -- on the side unless you like an ocean of it.  Note: the salad comes in a salad bowl that could feed the entire table, so if you are eating it alone, you may feel like a cow grazing in an endless pasture.  Also good are the thin-crust pizzas, especially the prosciutto and arugula, and the pasta like the rock shrimp tortellini in white cream sauce -- there goes the diet!  Although they look great, the roasted chicken always disappoints but the potatoes sometimes make up for it (yummy most likely due to soaking up the chicken fat).

Beverage: mediocre but passable wines.  Sometimes the red is served warm room temperature... yuck... so get a glass of white that comes out of the fridge.  Iced tea is a better bet with free refills.
author: Yan L.

description:
Went here with friends.  Great place to have a conversation over food.  

Enjoyed the food.  I had the special, gnocchi with pesto cream sauce.  The gnocchi was commercial (not homemade), though quite good.  Friends had tortellini (one Rock Shrimp, the other vegetarian).  Both enjoyed their dishes quite a bit.  

Will come back the next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: Brian L.

description: Great service, delicious food, and awesome location!  We ordered the fettucine alfredo and the chicken pesto pizza --- both were mmmmm mmmm good!  If you live in the castro area or are there for a visit - definitely check it out. You'll be glad you did!
author: K P.

description:
Still a good go-to place if I want to eat without a big wait or want to hang out for a while. They now have offer WiFi for free, so no hoping that there's an open network signal nearby. 

No more free drinks at lunch, that was nice while it lasted.
author: Michael M.

description:
Ate here on Sunday before heading to Dolores. 

Food was good, def comfort food. 

I'll be back.
author: Art A.

description:
Our first stop for my MAC & CHEESE MARATHON! A perfect start! The big table in the front was perfect for adding friends and was great to all meet up.

The mac and cheese here was actually  3 1/2 stars...nice and cheesey fresh parm on top, nice big noodles, and good size...it still needed something... so i added some fresh ground pepper and it was even better.
author: Tara S.

description: This place keeps disappointing me. If you order grilled chicken (1/2 a chicken) is a good price and you get a good size meal for $12 - . I just changed my choice tonight an picked a grilled salmon ($16.85 including tax) for a filet that was 1/2 a size of a single piece you would buy at the market to cook yourself. It was so thin that every bite fell apart when I picked it up with the fork.
author: E M.

description:
I dated a girl that lived in Noe Valley, and late one evening we decided to get pizza. She's an artist, so she started telling me about this pizza place where they display local artists works on the walls, and I was interested enough that we ended up taking a walk over there. And thats how I was introduced to Firewood Cafe.

The rotisserie chickens slow roasting in the window were temptation enough to go in, but once in there I couldn't resist getting a few slices of pie. The crust was doughy-and-yet-fluffy, with that taste of extra flour that come from hand-tossed dough. The food was brought to us real fast, and they did take plastic, so I have to give them positive stars for that alone. Also, they stay open pretty late - another bonus when you get those late night hunger pangs. Also, I like the fact that they support the local art scene. You don't see that too often nowadays.

Definitely worth going to, but the parking in Noe Valley can be a bit rough. On the other hand, you'll work up an appetite walking up or down the hills, so thats a bonus right there. I'll go back, you should too.
author: Maxx L.

description: The prices were reasonable and the portions were pretty big. I got pasta. :P A good place to eat lunch. I liked this place. I should try the salad and the pizza here sometime.
author: Farrah F.

description: Was with some friends and the sushi place across the street we originally intended to go to was closed so we decided to give Firewood a try. We were so happy we did! Friendly service and great food. I ordered a salad and tried the prawns and potatoes which were flavorful and delicious. Definitely will be back!
author: Michelle E.

description: When i lived in the Castro, I craved the house tortellini with white sauce. It was a hangover saver. very tasty. but be careful sometimes its not hot enough for some reason. so maybe they just take the precooked pasta and heat it up. either way... its really mouthwatering for me.  The salads come in big portions. The price is very reasonable. less expensive than average sf prices. I would literally have to stop my self from going in there and buying that dish.. probably caused a 10 pound weight gain..but it sure was good!
author: Shayenne G.

description:
The house tortellini with Firewood sauce (a creamy tomato sauce) is a personal favorite, and so is the herb-roasted 1/2 chicken.  It's easy to eat relatively healthy here (with some minor modifications), but it's also really easy to layer on the fat.   Choose prudently.  

If you're not feeling the pasta or the chicken, the salads are great if you can decide on a combo of salad toppings that don't make your salad cost $17.  The pizzas (why they have that darn firewood oven to begin with) aren't much to write home about.  

I like Firewood all right, but it always seems to cost more than it should.  Mixed feelings, but I do go back, so that should tell you something.
author: Evan G.

description:
3 Stars!! 

This place was perfect for what we needed it for. I play in a basketball league and we wanted to go out to eat as a team for dinner. There ended up being about 16 of us all together. It was nice to be able to all order at the counter and each get our own food. Very reasonable. The minus stars are mainly for the food. Its just blah food. Nothing special. So 3 stars for average.
author: Courtney Y.

description:
Truthfully, it took me a while to decide what to order because nothing on the menu sounded that good.  I settled on pork chops which were just fine, but nothing special.

My dining companion, however, had a ginormous salad that looked delicious.  I'll have to come back for a salad someday!
author: Marcus C.

description: This is a great place to go when you want a quick, fresh, healthy meal.  I'm not big on cooking at home, so I often come here alone for a quick bite.  The food is always delicious, with generous portions, and reasonable prices.  There is usually a spot at the counter, where you can sit with a glass of wine, a good meal, and watch the people go by.
author: Vance P.

description:
If you want extremely good value and very fresh ingredients this is it. It's mainly a salad place to me but other friends have ordered the chicken and other dishes which they liked very much.

It's TOTALLY a casual place. You order at the counter, take a table number and sit wherever you want. There's a long, long table in the center (which means you may elbow with othgers and strike up a conversation, there are window stools to sit on, and there's a cozy dining room up the stairs and in the back if you have a nice little or larger group with you.

Beer & wine is all they have in the class of libations.

And yes, you will always see "The Gays" there because it's i the middle of the Castro duh? But no one bothers anyone there...each into their own world except as I said, in the long center table (if it's crowded).
author: Lee S.

description:
Good place, yes.

Pasta, fresh pizzas, good price. What I really remember from here was a perfectly roasted chicken. Probably the best that I've had in SF. 

Not a lot of variety, but gooooood.
author: Javi V.

description:
Obsessed with their big caesar salad with chicken.

I don't order the pasta dishes; they don't seem to be a great value.

I LOVE the lady behind the counter (is it Martha?)...it's true she always smiles and I'd love to see her morph into a bitch just once....
author: Dwayne A.

description:
Firewood Cafe is a Quick Casual restaurant with dependable, fast, healthy and tasty food. Meals are usually $15 or less with a drink.

The chicken is tasty but the salads are killer (and HUGE). I also dig the occasional specials they have. I tried the Orange Mint Chicken yesterday and it was super tasty. I'm actually craving it today.

I haven't had any of the Italian food, but I definitely want to try the Prosciutto Pizza next time around.
author: Will K.

description: This is a good neighborhood cafe that serves fresh and tasty pasta, pizza and rotiserrie chicken. The chicken is excellent but very occasionally a bit overcooked. 90% of the time its awesome. The place is clean, bright and well appointed. You order and pay at the counter and a server delivers your meal to your table. With the 1/2 chicken you get very tasty roasted potatoes too. With a bottomless  soft drink it costs about $11. This is one of the best deals in the Castro. I've also had the Ceasar Salad with chicken...very good and big enough for two. I dont eat cheese but my friends say the pizzas are excellent. This is not fine dining but a great casual partial service fresh cafe. I recommend it.
author: Andreas M.

description:
this place was very good.

i think i remember the prices being kind of high and no parking.

i had a margharita pizza and pasta and some garlic on some bread.  it was all so fresh and tasty.

i was invited by a friend here from the neighborhood and the dinner was very good.  it turns out that my neighbor had thought it was a date...lmao.  i haven't been here since.

i did go to the other one at the metreon because i thought this one was sooo good.
author: Bing D.

description: I came here only once and tried one of the pasta dishes and it sure was good.  I plan on going back and updating my review.
author: Ricky M.

description:
Get the chicken tortellini with firewood sauce, add extra chicken breast to the top. Or get the ceasar salad with chicken... Although everything on the menu is awesome. 

Great, noisy, fun place for friends or kids, and Tuesdays are 20% off!
author: Cate F.

description:
I would give Firewood 5 stars if they didn't almost continuously, unerringly screw something up with my order. I'd say 50% of the time mine or a companions order is mismade or just plain forgotten. I'm not kidding, and I've been to either this Firewood or the one in the Metreon about 20 times total now. 

Other than that the food is quickly served and the atmosphere is nice for a chain restaurant. (Is it a franchise or is it just several restaurants privately owned in SF? I don't know.) When I go I mainly get the salad which is generous, tasty, and filled with your choice of about 10 different fresh ingredients.  On that note, why is it so hard to find a good salad in the city? Isn't this town stuffed with vegetarians, vegans, and other assorted vegetable lovers? 

Their chicken and pizza look and smell delicious, alas I cannot have these forbidden fruits because of my tendency towards caloric zealotry. 

This is a great place to go if you're in a bit of a hurry because the service is quite zippy (if they haven't forgotten your order: see above complaint). The one in the Metreon is a favorite of mine before a movie.
author: David Z.

description:
Good simple food.
Nothing too fancy or over the top.
BBQ chicken was great
salads rock.
author: Matt V.

description:
This is my place to go for a caesar salad fix; done their way.Order the large, and you get 3 added fixings. I throw in chicken as well.

My favorite combo-Chicken, blue cheese, roasted red peppers and the candied walnuts. yum. Not exactly healthy, but i feel good about getting my veggies, protein and plenty of fat with this salad.
author: Michelle S.

description:
The eats in the castro... um, in general just not fantastic (which is true for most gay villages in the US?) why? gays eat right?. 

 And okay, this may not be the answer, but... honestly,  I can rely on getting a nice green salad with chicken on top or better yet. .. I can order the roasted half chicken and substitute the small green salad for the roasted potatoes.  I am never disappointed. I'll take a pluto's salad over a firewood one, but... unfortunately... no plutos in the castro so this does the deed, just fine.

I
author: Alex D.

description: This is a great neighborhood restaurant and our "go to" place for lunch or dinner.. The food is wonderful, especially the baked rigatoni and sausage pizza. The service and staff are always top notch.
author: Sean G.

description:
Firewood is OK by y standards. It's good for what it is, but at the same time it is the kind of restaurant that you try one or two different things on the menu then stick with those because you are afraid of the disappointment you'll have if choice #3 doesn't live up to your expectations.

I must be talking about myself. I can't seem to force myself to try other things. Instead, I usually eat the Penne or the Rock Shrimp Tortellini. Both have yet to let me down and keep me coming back every once in a while. The service is so so, You order, they give you a big metal star with a number on it and then someone brings you your food...That's it.

The good thing about this place is occasionally they have a promotion for 2 days out of the week and you get a percentage off your meal. A good reason to go back...especially if you haven't found that perfect inexpensive Italian restaurant yet.
author: James J.

description:
I'm surprised to see some 2 star reviews for Firewood.  I really enjoy Firewood for what it is - a chain restaurant, with a smallish menu.

Firewood is a good spot to hit if you want a quick, relatively healthy meal.  No fries and burgers here -  6 or 7 pasta dishes, a few sandwich specials, some roasted chicken specials, a few pizza options and a few salads.  They also offer glasses of wine for a relatively cheap $4 - 6.

Rather than get table service, you order at the register & pay up front.  You also grab your own tableware and napkins, which is likely what keeps the prices as low as they are.  The ambiance is decent and clean enough, considering.  Location is spacious, and there are some large tables if you're in a big group that needs a quick bite.  There are little plates with olives at all the tables - not much of an olive muncher, but I have a few friends who enjoy the gesture.

The salads are where Firewood really rocks my socks.  You can start with either a Caesar or a Garden, at $7.  For an additional $2 or so, you can add chicken to your salad (you get a decent amount).  I've always picked the garden, and it has an abundance of lettuce, tomato, cucumber and carrots.  The bowls are HUGE...like serving bowl size.  There are four options for dressing.

Here's the kicker (in my book, anyway):  you also get to choose three "fixings" to add to your salad.   Things like caramelized onions, candied walnuts, green apples, pine nuts, bleu cheese, garbazno beans, etc.

I've also gotten salad to go there before, and it easily becomes two meals (if you get your dressing on the side).  For less than $10, that really ain't bad at all.

(If you want the perfect Firewood salad, I will graciously let you in on my personal combo:  The garden salad with chicken, and green apples, bleu cheese & candied walnuts. topped with the raspberry mustard vinaigrette.  Yummers!) 

To be fair - I've ventured off my menu mainstay twice and have encountered a bit less success.  One time I had a pasta, which was perfectly decent - but the portions were nowhere near as large as the salad and I found myself a bit hungry.  A second time I ordered up one of the sandwich specials...and didn't much care for it (although the side salad was tasty).

In general, though, I've almost always had a solid experience at Firewood.  It isn't fine dining by any stretch of the imagination, but it is a spot where you can get a delicious (and gi-normous) salad for $10...and be on your way within 20 minutes or so, if you are in a rush - which I often tend to be.
author: Christopher S.

description:
Ate here yesterday and haven't been in a while - nothing has really changed the menu is the same, thus the three star - it's decent, they give you a lot of food and the environment is conducive to groups which is always nice.

My fave dishes are the half roasted herb chicken, the salads (which are huge), and the penne.  Simple and seems to always hit the spot.  Keep up the good work, but at the same time the place needs to vary things up a bit and maybe change up the menu.
author: Tiberius A.

description:
Margharita Pizza done right. Not too crispy, not too saucy. 
Only available at this Firewood.
The one at Metreon doesn't seem to have the same touch.
author: Mary L.

description:
Great cheap and healthy food.  Can't beat the shrimp tortellini with the pink sauce, the pizzas are great and the salads are tops, although it's best to get the dressing on the side, they can make them a bit soggy.

It's a good choice in the neighborhood for quick, solid eats.

Park behind the Walgreen's in the metered lot, there is usually a space or two.
author: Tony A.

description:
This place is SO cute... 

I love their cucumber salad and their pastas! enough said. OH, their mint iced teas are great!
author: Charlage W.

description:
My husband and I were their first customers. The prices were so great and the portions so large that it was an absolute steal, especially because the food was so reliably good. Well, the prices have gone up and the portions have gotten smaller, but I think the quality is still quite high. And in today's market, the prices are still reasonable.

I really like their thin-crust pizzas, and all of the pastas are quite good. My husband still loves the first dish he had there, the penne pasta with white sauce. Their salads are generous. Their roasted chicken and roasted potatoes are first-rate. 

Still a great value. We also get take-out there frequently. Oh, they used to have fabulous olives on every table. Now you have to ask. But DO ask.
author: Marianne S.

description:
I've always been pretty ambivalent about Firewood.  Decent food in the neighborhood.  Not on the top of my list for places to go, but I'm happy to eat here every once in a while.  Never really thought about writing a review.

But then I had their Prosciutto Pizza.  This was remarkable.  And not in a good way.  

First, they slur the name "pizza" by calling it that.  Here's how its made:  They take a flavorless dough (tasted like a Carrs' Water Cracker), put a tiny amount of cheese on it and bake it.  Then they slice it, put one very thin (and cold) slice of prosciutto on each slice, and sprinkle a few arugula leaves on top.  An that's supposed to be a meal?  At best, it's a flavorless appetizer.  

If rated on this experience alone, it would be a one-star.  But the chicken is good and I've had decent meals here before, so it rises to three.
author: B D.

description:
The food is always really tasty and service is prompt and friendly.  The price is at the top end considering there is no table service and the decor could use some updating.  But overall a solid choice for italianish food in the stor.

P.S. if you get pasta choose the pink sauce
author: Jimmy M.

description: This place is right around the corner from where I live...and I've been there a handful of times.  I wanted to like it...but it's not that great.  The pizza is okay, the salads are a little blah, the pasta dishes are full of oil, and the prices aren't great for what you get.  Honestly...I hate chain restaurants...but California Pizza Kitchen could blow this place away.
author: Jon F.

description:
Did something happen at Firewood Cafe? I remember there was a nice selection of salads, sides and vegetables on display to the left of the counter. It used to be really tasty looking. 
I went today after not going there I guess a few years??? has it been that long?? anyways, I ordered garden salad with broccoli, beets and mushrooms. It was a pretty salad, good size for $8. My friends ordered capellini and rigatoni... they were appalled. It look liked little kid taking home ec class made it. They said the meal was "food court" quality. And the rigatoni.... I'm not sure if my friend read the menu wrong, but he was expectinng marinara sauce, no meat. He got meat. 
It was pretty warm day, so I say, hey, I'll take Foster on tap..... $5.50! well, it was a special treat to be out, so never mind complaining, just enjoying. 
I totally enjoyed he salad, but I missed all the sides they use to display. 
and just wondering, do you all tip? for the three of us, 1 tipped, 1 didn't and 1 says no comment. 
Service is ok.... more on the blah side. The staff all huddle around talking... and pretty much left us alone. 
Despite all that, I'll back for my garden salad and maybe try a pizza or two.
author: Lita T.

description: Used to be one of my favorites, but have had less-than-satisfactory visits recently. Tonight, they gave my order to another table and forgot about my serving entirely. When I went to check, they didn't apologize, but just asked if I wanted my order "to go." No, I wanted my money back. They never apologized for the mistake and lost a customer.
author: Rich W.

description: STOP and READ THIS!!! before you eat at this place. In addition to paying for your mediocre meal, they slap you with a 4% surcharge to pay for their employees health benefits under the San Francisco's New Health Care Security Ordinance. Now I have no problem with said ordinance, but the last time I checked the EMPLOYER is liable to pay this NOT the customer!!!  This is a rip off and sneaky on their part....oh and if you use your credit card to pay, they hit you with another $3!  GREEDY!!!!!! and SNEAKY!!!!! They lost my trust and my business forever.  Bastards!
author: Tintin and Snowy x.

description: Always a good time after Badlands' Friday happy hour.  I couldn't tell you what I've eaten but it's like the bar carries over to Firewood until the next venue.
author: S W.

description: Eating it as we speak! Backstory: a co-worker and I go out to eat in the Castro most Mondays after work.  Since we are not off til 9:30, the choice of restaurants has been limited.  We always walk to my car past this place but have never venture in.  We had taken peaks at the menu but would never take the plunge.  I finally went in alone and boy was I impressed.  I was able to get around their gourment menu but just telling them something I wanted that I hoped they could make.  I got noodles with sausage...sooooo good, but they need to give more bread when I say EXTRA bread!
author: John H.

description: The staff at this location is always friendly, accomodating and the food is delicious. I love that they'll custom alter any order as I love the firewood sauce yet the penne doesn't come with it.
author: Risa R.

description: Firewood is an excellent choice for affordable Italian in the Castro area (or at the Metreon - although it is closed for remodelling currently). It's the kind of place I have a favorite dish and I stick to it - the house tortellini with firewood sauce. Delicious. It comes with a piece of bread and it's very filling. I'd also recommend the salads, with choice of toppings. You can pick 3 with options such as caramelized onions, pine nuts, roasted red peppers, blue cheese, apples, candied walnuts, etc.. The salads are large and tasty. Finally, the customer service at Firewood excellent. I contacted them once about a wrong charge for a meal and they were incredibly helpful, quick to respond, and very apologetic. It's customer service like that, along with easy, good-tasting food that makes Firewood a place I highly enjoy!
author: Anne Q.

description: I eat here every once in a while.  I always get the penne pasta and I love it.  I've never had a bad meal here.  It's a good place to get non-fast food if you're kind of in a hurry too.
author: Norman M.

description: We have been getting dinner to go from this location once a week for a number of years.  It's satisfying and convenient, and they are willing to eliminate the mozzarella for us, which makes the pizza more heart-healthy  We prefer to take the food home since the mostly hard surfaces make for a "loud restaurant" experience.  I will say that the salads with chicken were better when they used their own moist, tasty roasted chicken rather than the somewhat dry grilled breast meat they use now.  Still, the salads are generously sized with a choice of interesting toppings.  The pizza is thin, crisp, and light.  A while back the prices took a jump and at the same time they started issuing email coupons.  So we made the decision to buy food here on "coupon night" since the full price was starting to creep up beyond our comfort zone.   In weeks when the coupons don't show up, or are restricted to a different location, we either get dinner elsewhere or share portions and eat less.
author: JB W.

description: It may not be the "Italian restaurant" you wanna go for Italina food, but it's cozy and the food is just yum yum yummy. My friends and I have ritual; we'd go there, and get three things for sure; the mushroom pizza, honey mustard chicken, and the caesar salad with at least candied walnut topping. The price is goodies and they serve wine too, so I am happy :). This is a happy place to eat and to just hangout with your friends without getting bothered with the waiters keep filling your water up and other stuff.
author: dannydan d.

description: A good place for lunch or an early dinner. I love rotisserie chicken so I go here, or the other one in the metreon, often...oh how I miss Gira Poli. If you're craving a "big salad" like Elaine, then this is the place for you. The pizzas ain't bad either. Overall, a decent dining experience.
author: Reza E.

description: This place has HUGE salads! (and they're pretty cheap) less then $8.00 I always get the Garden Salad with caramelized onions, candied walnuts, and roasted red peppers and a soda water. The BF and I come here fairly regularly. Tasty, cheap and fairly healthy. I've never had a bad experience here and the girl at the counter always seems to be in a good mood.
author: Dustin H.

description: The food is fresh and price is right. I'll definately eat here agin.
author: Brian M.

description: Really good tortellini - both house & vegetarian. Definitely don't pay full price though - go Mon/Tues and you'll feel like you got a really good deal (otherwise it's way too much). I prefer to take away my food, the atmosphere isn't anything special so you're better off watching tv at home w/ the pals.
author: Anika K.

description: I think this place is great.  Affordable, comfortable, tasty, and consistent.   The atmosphere is casual... you place your order with the cashier, pay, and then they bring it out to you when the food is ready.  It's solo-dining friendly too, with window counter seating.  On the menu, I like the huge garden salad that you can add toppings to like caramelized onions, candied walnuts, and green apples.  Or the cheese tortellini with the "Firewood sauce" -- half marinara and half alfredo.  Oh, and the warm bread pudding.  Comfort food, for sure.
author: Ryan L.

description: Quite good pizza for an order-at-the-counter-and-have-your-food-served place - the mushroom pizza came out within a few minutes and was delicious enough. We also ordered the sides platter, which was kind of a mixed bag. The red peppers and eggplant  were a bit too vinegary for my tastes, so I would stay away from them. I enjoyed the mozarella, but your tastes may vary. A fairly good value ($20 for 2), and the food came out pretty quickly.
author: Dana L.

description: Great food, great service.  Always consistent and clean (not common in the Castro).  Fair prices, and excellent customer service.  Firewood has a good menu with something on it to please everyone.  This makes it ideal for large groups.  I've eaten there many time and ordered several different dishes.  Consistently great food!
author: Nicholas E.

description: Came here with a good bud yeasterday to get a light lunch...went for the Margherita Pizza and us usual it didn't dissapoint.  Always reliable and consistant food.  For 2 individual pizzas and drink it was around $23.00...my only complaint was "where are the olives"? they usually have those on the tables??
author: Denny R.

description: Good for what it is...a quick, cheap neighborhood place to catch a bit to eat.  It's great for take-out on your way back home from a long day at work.  mmmm...especially linguine with clams in a white sauce...
author: Michelle P.

description: Sandwich and salad combo is my fave. BBQ chicken and caesar side salad...mmmm. The salad with chicken, and add 3 toppings (green apples, caramelized onions and candied walnuts) make for a meal as well. The staff is friendly and reasonable service speed. Go on a Monday or Tuesday for 20% (I think) off!
author: Alden C.

description: I have walked by Firewood a few times and it always looked like a decent place to eat.  I was a bit disappointed.  I had the mushroom pizza which was a decent meal, though it came out to me within two minutes time, which is always a red alert that it just popped out of the microwave.  I also got a platter of sides, which was way too vinegary.  The stuffed red pepper was cold, the mozzarella was flavor-less, and the eggplant was doused with balsamic vinegar, which I hate.
author: Joanna S.

description: The food here is pretty good - had the rock shrimp tortellini in the wine cream sauce mmmmm tasty! Mum had the veggie tortellini that was alright as well- I wasn't that impressed with the house tort though (which is what our friend got) The ambiance is pretty comfy and mellow. The waitstaff is very helpful especially when you ask them what is good, really friendly too.  Didn't have the pizza or rotisserie but I saw some people who got them and they looked really tasty too. I expect I will be back next time I make it up to the Castro!
author: Winter Lee S.

description: I am hesitant to give this place only two stars, but I think it is justified. Seeing their sign up for 20% off on Mon & Tues, I thought this would be a great chance to try a new restaurant and save some cash at the same time. The food was just ok - I've had much better Italian food for the same price. Second, and the most frustrating part, is what I found in my food. As a vegetarian, I made sure to choose one of the few vegetarian meals on the menu without having to customize one of those with meat in it already.  I got my order to go and when I got home, while eating my pasta, I found 3 pieces of bacon is my dish - not cool and was NOT mentioned on the menu.
author: Victoria K.

description: I like Firewood a lot - I go about once a week for lunch. Great salads, good chicken and pizza, friendly staff, pleasant atmosphere. One *big* lack is that while there are tons of great salad topping options, there are only 4 salad dressings (one of them is just the Cesaer dressing), and none of them are all that good. More, and better salad dressing options would raise them to five stars for sure!
author: City W.

description: I took my parents here for lunch when they came out to San Francisco to visit me so I wouldn't shock their midwest tastes too much. It's basically a glorified Pasta Pomodorro. The lunch was fine, I had a somewhat forgettable pasta dish that didn't really wow me. It all tasted and felt like a chain, which is cool if you're into that sort of thing. Not my scene.
author: Michael E.

description: I love the garden salad where you can add a gazillion toppings- my favorites, caramelized onions, candied walnuts and grilled chicken for protein lovers.  Service is decent but can be spotty at times.  Two weeks ago I was with a group of 6 and the salad order took over 30 minutes to show up- must have been a mess up in the kitchen.
author: Yew-Hoe T.

description: Go if for no other reason that the bottomless dish salad entrees -- tons of ruffage prepared as Caeser or Garden with tender chicken and any choice of toppings. On Mon/Tues you get 20% off, which makes it even more irresistable. The ovedn roasted chicken dishes are all succulent. I found the pastas to be middle of the road and some on the small portion side. I love the family style seating, the juicy olives waiting on the tables, and an always happy crowd. Great bet.
author: Eric P.

description: Only one experience here.  Pizza's were good, standard flavors and tastes.  Cesar salad was a bit flat.  Nice sunny side of the block location.  Paintings on the wall were the best part of my experience.
author: Grant T.

description: Average.  It was refreshing when it first appeared, but not it's rather boring I suppose. I do like the olive dish on the table, and the salads are enormous, but I have yet to have a juicy chicken on top of my salad, they always manage to find the driest parts to put on there :(
author: Ken B.

description: Everytime I come to this place, I am never disappointed! I love their pasta with peas, mushrooms, and pancetta dish! YUMMY!  Go for the experience and for their delicious menu! Reasonably priced!
author: Mel P.

description: Decent for a chain. I had the chicken and cheese tortellini and it was a bit too rich for me, especially after snacking at a superbowl party earlier. The salad looked like a perfect meal in and of itself so I'd probably go for that next.
author: Nate S.

description: Casual and nice to go hang after hitting a few bars with friends. No reservations needed and, great portions. THe chicken (with mustardy sauce) is finger lickin' good and, they had a special pizza one night of pear and gorgonzola which I keep trying to have them make everytime I go back. The salads are build your own and GInormous...and delicious.
author: L P.

description: Firewood is in the regular rotation of lunch spots I hit up with my brother.  Though I've pretty much only ordered a pizza or salad (or sandwich special) the food is very consistent and tasty.  I also like the space which provides several different seating options.  The olive dish on the table is a nice touch.  My only complaint is that while I never walk out hungry I always walk out feeling like I've spent just a little too much.
author: Jay W.

description: Couple years ago, I tried firewood. I remember I had very dry chicken with dry potatoes. My friends wanted to come here again this past Saturday, and since I'd already veto'd another place, I had to go along with it. Someone got the chicken, and he said it was dry, still. If you're gonna get rotisserie chicken, go over to cala market, its tastier. I wanted to get something different than last time, so I ordered chicken parm. Big mistake. It was gross but I ate it anyway. Very burnedy tasting and cardboardy hard. The pasta that came with it was better, but nothing special. There were veggies - summer squashes, which usually I like, but didn't this time. Leaving there, I felt naseous and headachey. I had to take tylenol and take a nap and I felt really yucky. Next time my friends want to eat here, I'll just sit with them rather than have more bleh food and feel yuk after. 2 of my friends tried mine and agreed that it was bad. Roomie and I stuck ours on the same bill. He had the salmon, which he said was mostly those dried up potatoes with about 2 bites of salmon. He was hungry after. I might add that between the 2 of us, we paid more for our unsatisfying bleh meal than last night at barneys, where we paid less, got more food, which was tasty and no one got sick.
author: Merredith L.

description: In general, I don't think the Castro has a lot of great food options.  This is one of the better ones.  The have great salads and great pizzas.  It's kind of a create-your-own menu in these areas.  I generally find the candied walnuts, applies and blue cheese to be an excellent addition to the salad... a little chicken always seems in order as well.  It's darn good and satisfying.
author: Jenn M.

description:
I went here this past Friday night, 3-13-09.  Went to the bathroom, one of the cooks arrived in the bathroom a little after me.  I start washing my hands, the cook got done with his business then walked right out, didn't wash his hands or even seem to look at the sink.

Went to report it to the manager, she gave me a dirty look and did not seem to care.  Thank you very much, will never eat here again.
author: E H.

description: Huge fresh salads with nice selection of sides....perfect place to sit and chat with a great friend when time is not an object.  Big fan of booths and the top tier is full of 'em.
author: Kala H.

description: Local haunt (while in the Castro).  Consistent.  Great salads, chicken and (very) thin-crust mushroom pizza.  Caesar salad with chicken, mushrooms, corn and grilled onions.  Yum!!!
author: M W W.

description: While on vacation and before going out for the evening, a friend and I ate here.  I had the roast pork loin and he had the prawn dish.  Both were good.  He could stand to have another prawn or two in his meal, but he could also stand to eat his vegetables (tsk tsk).  The pork loin was cooked perfectly (not dried out), and the vegetables and potatoes were delicious.
author: Jason S.

description:
The health inspector just gave them a scary score of 70.  According to the health department: there were rodents/roaches/flies, food contact surfaces were not sanitized, food held at improper temperatures, and non-food surfaces were not clean.  Only 2% of restaurants in SF earn a lower score.  

In addition to vigorously addressing these issues, I wish they would update their menu.  It has become boring...particularly their bland potatoes.  It's a cheap and boring side dish.  It's time for a complete overhaul of the menu, folks, really.
author: Adam H.

description: Salad heaven! Firewood's salads are my 'death row' meal...if I had to eat a last meal, it would be the Firewood Chicken Caesar salad with 3 toppings and Herb Vinaigrette (instead of Caesar dressing). The salads are so yummy and delish and satisfying and definitely an entree-size salad. These salads are also perfect for taking to a get-together...I've had people rave about salads I've brought to parties. On the few times I have dared to veer from my salad mainstay, their pastas and pizzas have been divine. For a casual dinner or lunch, it's the perfect stop. Also, the Castro location is by far the best!
author: Shelley F.

description: I enjoy having that big bowl of salad with chicken. The options for dressings are not the best, but still is a good salad. Sometimes I like to try their pizza which has a very thin crost. When I am hungrier I like to eat half of the haney-dijon glazed chicken with roasted potatos with the taste of rosemary leaves. It's great!
author: carlos f.

description:
Sorry everyone, but my fiance and I went here yesterday (Sunday, 9/14) and the customer in front of us spotted a cockroach crawling on the counter near the register. The guy working the register tried to kill it with the towel he had in his hand but then lost it and then looked at us to take our order - ummm....no thanks.
We left immediately...despite the fact that we called in our order 15 minutes ago and were just there to pick up our dinner. We weren't too disappointed as the one pizza we had there a few weeks ago wasn't that great and we ended up going down the street to another pizza joint on 18th and Castro instead...even with our Firewood Cafe pizza box. 

Cockroaches though...sorry, but I can't ever go back to a place that has a problem with cockroaches!
author: Julia S.

description: Before it closed for renovation, I went to the Firewood Café at the Metreon often and really looked forward to it.  I now go to the Castro location which I always found a notch below the one at the Metreon in quality.  However, it features the same menu and recipes and is still worth the trip.  I usually get the sausage pizza with light sausage and extra peppers and onions.  They make their pizzas with a light thin crispy crust and perfect proportion of cheese, sauce and toppings and the whole thing is delicious.  As far as I'm concerned, this is the best pizza in town!  Now and then I get the roast chicken, which is correct and a very good buy.  I've tasted the pastas and they are, again, correct and tasty for a reasonable price.  All-in-all, a very good inexpensive dinner out.
author: Robert S.

description: Thanks to recommendations from Chad, a long time resident of the Mission/ Castro/ Dolores park neighborhood that I can now call home (who obviously knows the best places to eat), I paid a visit to the Firewood Cafe located just up the hill on 18th street. Around 9 on a Thursday, we were famished and walked into this cheery fast food sit down hybrid of a restaurant salivating over the myriad options on the menu. As I was told to come for the chicken, we opted to share the herb roasted bird (which I could watch roasting on the spit- ah fond memories of Zankou in Pasadena) and a salad composed of mixed greens, roasted beets, corn, and avocado. The salads here are at the mercy of your own culinary abilities- you pick the ingredients! I'll admit, it can be a bit overwhelming, what with all the choices, but I didn't feel the panic that arose when I found myself in a similar situation back at the 21 choices frozen yogurt shop (yes, 21 choices of topping and flavors was just too much- I couldn't handle it). We sat down at a table near the window and while waiting for the food to arrive snacked on a delicious olive medly and fresh bread. The salad arrived first, soon followed by the crispy bird, skin seasoned perfectly and meat mouthwateringly tender. The portions were huge, and the price completely affordable.  I recommend sharing both the chicken and the salad- it would be way too much for one person.
author: Kate A.

description: Have been here a few times, most recently Saturday night after seeing the excellent French film "L'Intrus [The Intruder]", directed by Claire Denis, at the Castro Theatre. My CinemaSnobs friends/group had reserved the large table in the back, and we came here for dinner afterwards to discuss the film. Firewood is a small chain with other locations at the Metreon and Boarding Area A, International Terminal, SFO airport (called Firewood Grill there). That should tell you something.  The interior is nicely-appointed, though fortunately that is not reflected in the reasonable prices, offset 20% on Mondays and Tuesdays. The Italian-focused menu is limited, featuring well-prepared enormous salads with your choice of a wide variety of toppings, pizza from their applewood-fired oven, pastas such as their homemade tortellini, and fresh crispy juicy rotisserie chicken. You order at the counter (thus the bargain prices) and a runner brings the food to your table, which are all stocked with a small saucer of olives, a nice touch that I like. The fire-roasted new potatoes, $2.95 as a side, tossed with fresh herbs, olive oil, and garlic, which I've had in the past, are particularly good, with their chicken. Saturday night I had the salmon special with a balsamic glaze and small green salad, $12.20, which I enjoyed. The salmon had a nice flavor and you could taste the balsamic glaze. Wine is not that expensive at $4.50-5.50 for a glass, $18-21 for a bottle, when I've seen starting prices at $7 a glass at higher-end restaurants. A good place to dine alone on scrumptious roast chicken, size up future dates, get cheap food, host large groups, make reservations, or any combination of the aforementioned.
author: Hao L.

description: I only go for the olives. But Olives are similar to bacon in that it's pretty difficult to screw them up. Firewood is where I go when at the Metreon or baby-sitting in the Castro, because children love Firewood Cafe. Firewood lacks atmosphere and the staff is sooooo unfriendly. I was there with a disabled child a few weeks ago and they were so unfriendly, unhelpful, and just downright rude that between the staff and the difficult child I was with, I found myself near tears. They score big points for the level of accessibility to disabled patrons- a wheelchair ramp, large restrooms, etc. Their house tortellini is also yummy and the salads are large, if unimaginitive. I think they're a little overpriced for such generic, run-of-the-mill chain restaurant fare. I don't mind shelling out for yummy food, but a lot of their dishes simply don't taste like much. The bland flavors and rude folks behind the register means I probably won't be back to this location and I'll only pop into the Metreon Branch (where the staff are so much nicer) when I'm already there for a movie.
author: Autumn K.

description: i find the salads sort of boring, but omigod, the house tortellini is unbelievable.  i don't usually like chicken in my pasta dishes, but something magical is going on with this tortellini.
author: Angela M.

description: Chicken caesar rocks here. Add broccoli, apples, carmelized walnuts, get dressing on the side and prepare for a full meal.
author: Torsten K.

description: In this restaurant you order first, then take a number and find a table, wait for your food.  I ordered the wood-fired pizza special with mushrooms and pepperoni.  The pizza was great, thin crusted, with a nice bodied marinara sauce. I had the tiramasu for dessert, and i higly reccomend it as well - perfect texture, flavor and a big enough serving to share!  I rated this establishment as a three because the service was lees than par.  The lady behind the counter didn't seem especially happy to answer questions about the menu, and the cooks behind the counter wouldn't help either - they pretended to only speak Spanish - which is fine I'm fluent, however they ignored me even after i repeated in Spanish.  I went with a group of friends and they brought him the wrong plate - and played it off as what he had ordered, rotisserie chicken, and penne - they sound the same to me.  Regardless - he liked the chicken.
author: J.D. H.

description: Very good, very reasonably priced food, although the booze is overpriced. The chicken in particularly is excellent and the salads with the ad ons are great...it is a small chain (two locations) but good, fast, and reasonable.
author: Darien W.

description:
While moving into the neighborhood, I went to get some take-out from here because it's just around the corner from my new place. I'm vegetarian, and ordered the vegetarian tortellini. I specifically asked the guy who took my order (who I think was the manager) if the sauce I got was veggie. Turned out, they gave me shrimp tortellini, and I ate a few pieces before I realized it. Furious, I called them and told the woman on the phone what happened. She was all "ummm, okay?" Her tone was basically like, "I don't care, and what do you expect me to do about it anyway?" I asked to speak to the manager, and at least he was quick to oblige when I requested that my credit card be refunded. That may earn them another half star, but the attitude of the woman on the phone negates it. I could've seen myself coming here for take-out fairly often, even though the food is mediocre at best, just because of the convenience and proximity to my new place. But now, never again.

The most unfortunate part is that it wasn't even good - I may have been slightly less upset if I had accidentally broken my vegetarianism and at least enjoyed it a little. But probably not.
author: K. E.

description: not expensive, great food, fast - amazing, i love it
author: Scott K.

description: The "make-your-own-salad" is quite a sure winner, although this place is a bit overpriced... Try going on Monday or Tuesday when they knock 20% off your bill...
author: Michael H.

description: i wish i could like firewood!! i love the bbq sandwich but the salads were nasty and the pasuito pizza was nasty too.. the arugala needed something and very small pieces of pasuito.. it was okay for the price
author: Shauna P.

description: You need to stop goofing around and go eat a salad so that you stay healthy. Thus, you need to go to Firewood and have a contest of wills with one of their very good, and very big salads. Yum!
author: Todd E.

description: Good, cheap food! I love this place because there is no waiting and the food is good, although I always get pizza or salad. The chicken is good too, but I hate eating off the bone so I don't order it.
author: Michael G.

description: Though this place has been there for a long time, i had my first experience (and last) this week.  The menu is simple and actually the food is good for the price.  I had the pizza.  However, the staff is less then adequate.  Cooks on their cell phones and the cashier /order taker was a real nasty character.  The place, oddly enough for the Castro, was packed with children and very noisy.  It reminded me of a "Chucky Cheese" for gay families.  And probably not a bad place to go for kids. Simple food and simple to order.  But for anyone else, there are so many better places to go so why bother with the attitude here.
author: Mark H.

description: "I just drove by the Firewood Cafe in Castro and was pleasantly surprised to see their 20% off everything special is back! It is an incredible deal for a great neighborhood restaurant. They have home-made pasta and very good thin-crust pizza. I have always enjoyed their food and service. Now I can enjoy all that for less."
author: Nan C.
